urn:contentItem:5W4G-WT31-DYRW-R2JB-00000-00Alibaba's Jack Ma says he is 'worried' Europe will stifle innovation with too much tech regulation2019-05-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:08:51ZLexisNexisCHNAlibaba's Jack Ma says he is 'worried' Europe will stifle innovation with too much tech regulation Zen Soo in Paris

Jack Ma, Alibaba Group executive chairman and co-founder, on Thursday urged Europe to stop worrying about technology, as tighter regulation could hamper its ability to innovate.

He pointed to China as an example of how a lack of regulation around the internet in the early days allowed China's mobile internet to flourish and for Alibaba to thrive. Alibaba is the parent company of the South China Morning Post.

"[Back then] most of the government officials didn't know how to make rules and laws for the internet, because nobody realised what the internet looked like," Ma said at the VivaTech conference in Paris. "That gave us the chance to grow fast."

He added that in China, entrepreneurs "start to solve problems" first before thinking about regulation, but suggested that Europe's tendency to regulate once it becomes worried about a certain issue could be stifling innovation.

Compared to the US, whose Silicon Valley has produced the likes of Facebook and Google, as well as China with its technology powerhouses like Alibaba, Tencent and Baidu, Europe lags behind in terms of technology innovation and has not produced as many big tech firms.

Tech revolution could cause another world war, Jack Ma warns

"Europe ... everything you do follows rules and laws. Everything you think about, when you start to worry, you make rules and laws," he said. "I worry about Europe, and I worry about the worries of Europe."

Ma's comments come as Europe looks to tighten technology regulation. Last year, the continent put in place the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), a set of data protection rules for all companies that have operations in the region to ensure they gather personal data legally and protect that data from being misused.

The European Commission, as well as European nations including France, Germany, the Netherlands, Spain and the UK, joined New Zealand's rallying call on Wednesday to curb online extremism via a series of measures aimed at holding tech companies more accountable for the content published on their platforms.

In April, the European Union (EU) released guidelines on developing artificial intelligence (AI) ethically.

Ma suggested that worries about AI and the dangers it presents are overblown, pointing out that while AI can be used for bad, it can also be used for good. He used Alibaba as an example, pointing out that the company uses AI to "catch a lot of thieves" who wish to steal from the millions of payment transactions made on its platform every day.

"[Europe worries] that you don't have the solution to artificial intelligence, that it may destroy a lot of things ... forget it," said Ma. "Bad guys are using artificial intelligence to do bad things, but we're using artificial intelligence to catch bad guys [on Alibaba]."

"There's always a yin and yang balance, how you see the world," said Ma, referring to the Chinese philosophy of inseparable and contradictory opposites. "If you see the technology revolution as a problem, I'm sorry to say the problem just started. If you think it's an opportunity, the opportunity just started."

urn:contentItem:5XCD-BX11-DY2H-61X1-00000-00Alipay, Tencent beware: China's digital yuan is closing in2019-10-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:08:51ZLexisNexisAlipay, Tencent beware: China's digital yuan is closing in

Chinese billionaires Jack Ma and Pony Ma, who built their online finance empires by dominating the country's online payments industry, are facing what could be the strongest competitor yet: the central bank. The People's Bank of China is set to provide its own electronic version of the yuan soon, potentially the first major central bank in the world to issue a digital national currency. In doing so, the PBOC is throwing down the gauntlet to Ant Financial's Alipay and Tencent Holdings Ltd.'s WeChat Pay for a share of China's $27 trillion payments industry. In China, smart-phone-based electronic payments are ubiquitous, used for everything from bus-rides and convenience stores to vegetables at the local market -- and 94% of those transactions are controlled by the two firms.

Yet private-sector primacy in a critical industry is becoming a rarity in China under President Xi Jinping, spelling tougher times ahead for the tech giants. A central bank-backed digital wallet could severely undermine the payments services that are the beating heart of Ant's and Tencent's businesses. "The central bank is trying to regain the power it lost, as it simply can't allow private companies to dominate payments which lie at the heart of the finance system," said Zhu Chen, the founder of Wisburg, a Shanghai-based financial and research consultancy. He forecasts that the PBOC could take as much as a third of the payments business. "Expect some big blows to WeChat Pay and Alipay," he said. Much remains unclear about the threat that the digital yuan will pose to the existing businesses, including the extent to which the public will be willing or required to take it up. Executives from both companies have also not commented on it in public, though Ant Financial has worked with the regulator on it. The PBOC has yet to set a time-line or plan of implementation, but official speeches suggest it could work something like this: Consumers and businesses would download a digital wallet on their mobile phone and load the token from their account at a commercial bank -- similar to going to an ATM. They then use that like cash to make and receive payments. That's subtly different from the existing mobile payments function, which are essentially processing claims on a bank account much like a debit or credit card. But the state token, if it gains acceptance, would help Chinese regulators maintain a better grasp of the country's money supply. Mobile payments for consumption represent 16% of gross domestic product in China, compared with less than 1% in the U.S. and U.K. where credit cards are more popular. As the nation becomes essentially cashless, the authorities have been paying ever more attention to the companies that operate the financial plumbing. "Those big tech companies bring to us a lot of challenges and financial risks," Yi Gang, China's central bank governor, said during a conference earlier this year. "You see in this game, winners take all, so monopolies are a challenge." Zhu reasons that if Chinese regulators see payments as a sector of vital strategic importance, then the state will target at least one third of market share to achieve control. The usefulness of a payment function to the general public has proven to be so great that both Tencent and Alipay have been willing to pour billions into the business just to win market share. Even though they are inherently loss making -- free to the user but incurring fees from banks -- payment services are a key way to keep nearly a billion people using the apps and available to buy other finance services. Already Chinese regulators have curbed one of Alipay and WeChat Pay's most lucrative businesses - the interest they gain from escrow funds. The PBOC has also reclaimed its authority in the clearing and settlements service, requiring all third party payment systems to connect to a company called Nets Union Clearing Corp. that links with the central bank. That's effectively stopped the duo playing the role of what Yi described as a "second central bank." China's ruling party is adamant about the state controlling key sectors that pose systemic risk -- finance being one of the most important. "We have to have the borderline between central bank and big tech companies," said Yi. Ant Financial, owner of Alipay, and Tencent declined to comment for this story. The PBOC didn't respond to a fax seeking comment on their digital currency plans. It won't be easy to uproot the mighty incumbents though. For years, users have linked their bank saving cards to the apps, which also include a wide range of other useful services, to pay for daily outlays. Alipay and WeChat Pay each have more than 900 million active users in the country. The simple part of the plan is that the token could replace existing cash -- part of an effort to prevent money laundering -- but if the PBOC wants to win more payment share, it will have to build a network where merchants are willing to accept the token directly. That would require a lot of work, said Ryan Zheng, co-founder of RiverPay, which helps Alipay and WeChat Pay connect with merchants. The risk for the PBOC is that adoption is weak, undermining the institution's reputation. That's a concern on the minds of many central banks around the world also grappling with the impact of digital payments and currencies. To listen to PBOC officials though makes it clear that these are just practical considerations beside the bigger themes at stake. "Currency means interest, power, global politics and diplomacy," said Wang In, director of the People's Bank of China research bureau, during a conference this year. "If a payments tool can provide the function of a currency, then it will definitely have impact on legal tender, and affect how a country manages its currency and financial system."

Lulu Yilun Chen & Zheping Huang

urn:contentItem:5Y7X-RJY1-JD39-X41S-00000-00Alison Rowat: Don't knock it when Amazon wealth comes knocking2020-02-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:08:51ZLexisNexisAlison Rowat: Don't knock it when Amazon wealth comes knockingAlison Rowat

FOR a country that has done everything constitutionally possible to avoid having a king, America is producing them at an impressive rate.

There is King Donald (Trump), vanquisher of impeachment; King Mike (Bloomberg), who graciously joined the other Democratic hopefuls in a televised debate for the first time last night in Nevada; and King Jeff (Bezos), Amazon chief executive.

Mirror mirror on the wall, who is the most powerful of all - Donald the President, Mike the media mogul, or Jeff the richest man on the planet?

Mr Bezos is the most confusing, judging by two takes on him this week. In the first, a Panorama investigation, Amazon: What They Know About Us, the tech titan and his company were judged by some observers to be data vultures feeding off customers' information, their activities posing a threat to democracy and freedom. One retailer, who alleged his small business was ruined after getting involved with Amazon, even compared the firm to the devil. We saw also a high street bookseller, in tears, locking up her shop for the last time. She could not compete on prices and speed of delivery, so the shop had to close.

But then there was the other Jeff Bezos, the one who gave $10 billion (£7.7 billion) of his fortune to the fight against climate change. If you have a good idea about how to save this spinning rock from rising temperatures, the Bezos Earth Fund wants to hear about it.

"Climate change is the biggest threat to our planet," the entrepreneur wrote in an Instagram post.

READ MORE: Before you click think of the damage you are doing

"This global initiative will fund scientists, activists, NGOs - any effort that offers a real possibility to help preserve and protect the natural world. We can save Earth. It's going to take collective action from big companies, small companies, nation states, global organizations, and individuals ... ⁣⁣⁣Earth is the one thing we have in common - let's protect it, together." Just when you were wondering what you had in common with someone worth $130 billion, along comes the answer.

So which one is the real Jeff Bezos, a superhero out to save the planet with dollars instead of special powers, or the Jeff Bezos whose company is deemed a threat to democracy and freedom?

Questioning the motives of those extremely wealthy individuals who give to charity has become commonplace. While praising Andrew Carnegie for giving fortunes away to help and educate others, we nevertheless remember that he made his money through the blood and sweat of workers, as did every capitalist of his age. Many are the universities who have accepted legacies, only to be taken to task generations later by students questioning the morality of how the money was made.

In Bezos's case, customers have come to look anew at Amazon, and the rest of the big tech companies, and wonder what has been invented on our watch.

READ MORE: Licence fee 'outdated'

Yet in most cases the customer willingly gave over the information they now deem so precious. Who put all those personal details into Facebook? Who has ever read the terms and conditions or privacy policy? How many of us have bought an Alexa smart speaker and speak to it more often than we do aged relatives or other members of the family?

Alexa is a perfect example of our love/suspect relationship with technology and, by extension, those who have made vast fortunes from it. In January it was reported that sales of Alexa-enabled devices had passed the 100 million mark. Though Amazon did not break the total down into its speakers and other products, the extent of the tech revolution that has taken place in our homes is breathtaking.

I remember when smart speakers first appeared. There was no end to what you could ask Alexa to do, from order dog food to play your favourite music and find out what the time and temperature was anywhere in the world.

How clever we thought we were, how much time we could save. Then the whispers and doubts began. Sure enough, it wasn't just the machines listening. Humans were doing it as well.

Big tech said only a tiny fraction of conversations were monitored, and that it was only done to improve the service, but customers were unnerved and rightly so.

READ MORE: Amazon target site for wind farm plans

The biggest joke of all was that people had paid for the devices they now accused of infringing their privacy. One former Amazon executive interviewed by Panorama said he still had Alexas in his home but he turned them off if he wanted to have a private conversation. I expect after watching the programme that many more will do the same.

There is a backlash building against Big Tech, with the race on to see how governments can tax and regulate them better.

If one was cynical, Mr Bezos's setting up of a $10 billion fund, like Mark Zuckerberg's call this week for greater regulation, can be seen as the tech titans once again trying to stay ahead of the curve.

Doing good things, saying the right things, to reframe the debate in their favour; tinkering at the edges when what they really should be doing is paying more tax, assuming greater responsibility for their actions, and reducing their own carbon footprint. Anyway, how much difference can $10 billion make given the size of the problem faced?

The Amazon chief executive is not the only fantastically rich person having his actions questioned. Mike Bloomberg, whose charitable giving down the years makes the odd billion here and there look positively peanut-sized, is feeling the heat too, with a rival for the Democratic nomination, Elizabeth Warren, calling him an "egomaniac billionaire" and saying it was a "shame" he was able to "buy his way into the debate".

It is right to be cautious about where vast wealth comes from and what it is used for, but at the same time we should give credit where it is due. Mr Bezos did not have to offer $10 billion, and his action, together with those of other wealthy individuals handing over enormous amounts, should be welcomed.

Now about those taxes ...

Warning: If you don’t work for a big tech company, reading beyond this point could make you green with envy.Handing big stock grants to work...

Warning: If you don’t work for a big tech company, reading beyond this point could make you green with envy.

Handing big stock grants to workers has long been a way for tech start-ups to attract talent. The chance to hit the lottery is an important part of the Silicon Valley myth.

As the great bull market reaches new heights, however, this has turned into a gravy train of unprecedented proportions. The reliable profits — and steadily rising shares — of Big Tech have removed the risk, turning stock grants into a core part of the annual earnings package for many tech workers.

The figures have become truly gargantuan. Alphabet, parent of Google, handed out $13.5bn worth of restricted shares to employees in the first nine months of the year — around $127,000 a head. Facebook went further, with stock awards averaging about $200,000.

The big run-up in stock prices, led by tech, has supercharged the gains. Workers typically have to wait four years for their restricted stock to vest. Back in 2015, the average value of the stock awards Facebook handed out was $235,000. Now, as they become available for sale, those same shares are worth around $580,000 a head.

Shareholders have been happy to go along with all of this. Stock benefits have become a worker expectation that no successful tech company can afford to ignore. With a war for talent raging in Silicon Valley, locking in the most valuable workers for four years is critical.

Also, as share prices have risen across the board, outside investors have been more than happy to turn a blind eye to the handouts that dilute their own stakes — something that may not continue in a downturn.

Richer companies have more than enough surplus cash to soak up the effects of this employee stock bonanza. Google, where stock buybacks averaged a modest $6bn over the past three years, ramped up the repurchases to $12bn in the first nine months of 2019. Facebook, which only began to buy back its stock two years ago, repurchased $9bn.

Life is harder elsewhere. Salesforce, the leader among cloud-based business application companies, is emblematic of the way that stock grants have delayed a move into meaningful profit. It reported $374m in net profits in the first nine months of 2019 — a period in which it handed out $1.3bn in stock benefits.

Over time, this has also diluted the holdings of other Salesforce investors, with stock grants being a big factor behind a 40 per cent growth in the company’s share count over the past five years.

Even for the richest companies, the effects are significant. The value of employee stock is greater than the figures that jump out from a casual glance at the companies’ income statements.

Facebook, for instance, recorded $3.6bn of stock-based compensation expenses in the first nine months of this year — which trimmed 24 per cent from its reported profits. But that is only part of the $8bn worth of restricted stock it handed out in the period. The rest has been carried forward, along with stock expenses from prior periods, leaving the company with more than $12bn in charges to be taken against future profits.

Silicon Valley was up in arms when regulators first forced US companies to start deducting employee stock grants from their profits. Tech companies argued that promising start-ups that lacked the cash to pay big salaries would be dealt a lethal blow if they were penalised for using stock as a lure.

After the rule change, most tech companies simply added the stock-based compensation expenses back to their earnings, yielding a preferred profit figure they showed to Wall Street. Investors have been more than happy to go along with these (higher) pro forma profit figures.

For Big Tech, however, profit-enhancing measures like these are no longer needed. In fact, with envy at their huge wealth and market power growing, it probably pays to take some of the shine off the bottom line.

Two years ago, some of the biggest companies moved in unison to abandon the pro forma figures. Stock-based compensation expenses have sliced more than 25 per cent from reported earnings at Alphabet this year. But it has still been churning out after-tax profits of more than $600m a week.

So as a bountiful decade draws to a close: Let the good times roll!

urn:contentItem:5X64-6YB1-JDK8-V0MS-00000-00All-American Kiwi kids ? internet dominates TV time2019-10-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:08:51ZLexisNexisBUSINESSPg. A016All-American Kiwi kids ? internet dominates TV time

Streaming services look set to increase the influence of overseas content

As a wounded Spark battles away in the streaming trench of its own making, a much bloodier fight brews in the Kiwi living room - and it could change the way our kids talk.

Data from broadcaster TVNZ, released this week, indicates that we've reached an important tipping point in the way viewers watch online content.

For the first time since records began, the broadcaster has noted that more people are now watching on-demand content through connected TVs than through desktops or mobile devices.

What this means is that the internet - and everything it offers - is now at the centre of the Kiwi living room, and there'll be no turning back from this point.

This trend has been given a shot of adrenaline by the Rugby World Cup, which has left Kiwis with little choice but to get connected if they want to watch the games at home.

And the nation has responded to the change - albeit in the classic last-minute Kiwi way - with data from product comparison site PriceSpy showing that interest in television media players more than doubled in September, compared with the same month last year, as viewers scrambled to find out more about Google Chomecast devices and Apple TVs.

If Spark can take credit for getting one thing right, it's ripping streaming away from just the early adopters and shoving it directly into middle New Zealand without asking permission. There have certainly been awkward moments for some of the technically challenged among us, but long after the mud dries on the knees of this year's World Cup Winners, the TVs connected during the event will remain in the living room, blaring out on-demand content.

This change will give more New Zealanders access to a wider spread of content options than they've ever had before. But it also puts this country at the centre of what marketing academic Mark Ritson recently tipped to become "the bloodiest battle in marketing history".

What Ritson is referring to is the fight for supremacy among the tech and media juggernauts all vying for control of the biggest screen in our everyday lives. Netflix, Apple, Amazon, Google, Disney and HBO are just some of the players spending a fortune to get viewers locked into their platforms.

Pitted against the billions of dollars Netflix or Apple have, local broadcasters face a challenge for relevance unlike anything they've seen since television emerged.

All this choice might seem great on the surface, but as more of our daily media minutes are shifted to international providers we'll start to see a number of unintended consequences that could have a direct impact on Kiwi culture.

Cookies, diapers and candyAs far back as 2016, a study by Colmar Brunton found that 40 per cent of parents were concerned about the influence of American and international content on their kids.

"We have heard from lots of parents that they want their children to hear our stories. They also want to hear them in our accent and in our languages. It's hugely important to parents," TVNZ general manager of product and data Carmen Aitken tells the Herald.

Aitken says she still consistently hears from parents who are concerned about kids slipping Americanisms into their daily vernacular, from watching overseas content.

A unscientific poll among parents in the Herald newsroom found that words such as "cookies", "candy", "diapers" and "gas" have become common replacements for their predecessors : "biscuits", "lollies", "nappies" and "petrol". And this is only set to increase, with YouTube steadily dominating screentime among younger viewers.

One way to look at this is that mimicry is a normal part of growing up and that children tend to parrot what they see in those around them.

Another way to look at it, however, is in terms of the power media have to influence how we behave. This is often referred to as "cultural currency", and it plays a big role in terms of defining what we admire and who we look up to.

If Kiwi kids are predominantly fed narratives from abroad from a young age, what space does that leave for the local stories and colloquialisms that have been shaped over decades?

This is part of the reason why NZ On Air has invested heavily in programming on TVNZ's ad-free children's platform Heihei. The hope being that parents will choose the local option before venturing abroad.

The content watched by our tamariki is only part of the complexity we're walking into. Another concern is the way in which data is captured from a young age.

Just recently, YouTube was fined more than US$170 million ($271m) for collecting children's personal data while they were watching videos. The problem is that locally we are largely powerless against this until something happens abroad. The giants of the tech world aren't going to change their habits on the basis of what we scream from our corner of the world.

At least local broadcasters can be held accountable by regulators and lawmakers here in New Zealand. TVNZ's Aitken says they only capture the name, gender and age of their users and that this information is not shared with any third party advertisers. If in the future TVNZ is caught breaking this rule and misusing data or distributing content that's unsafe for children, we have local measures that can hold them to account. The same cannot be said of any of the big tech companies that run their businesses from abroad.

So as we head into a streaming-first world, the question for parents is who they trust to look after their kids' eyeballs. Our local broadcasters or the "don't be evil" crew in Silicon Valley?

- NZ Herald

urn:contentItem:4KY2-F3C0-TXJ2-N2F2-00000-00All calm in North American markets2001-03-14T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:08:51ZLexisNexisREPORT ON BUSINESS: INTERNATIONALPg. B1All calm in North American marketsGUY DIXONWith a file from reporter Susanne Craig in New York

U.S. stocks regained ground, Canadian equities inched higher and all turned relatively tranquil in the stock market yesterday, despite a stream of negative earnings estimates from a variety of companies.

In marked contrast to Monday's sudden freefall, enough buyers returned to push equities higher, even as such industry standard-bearers as Delta Air Lines Inc. and German engineering and electronics company Siemens AG lowered their earnings forecasts and Motorola Inc. announced 7,000 additional layoffs.

But with buying momentum continuing right to the close, the technology-laden Nasdaq Stock Market recouped much of Monday's fall, rising 91.4 points, or 4.75 per cent, to 2,014.78. This ended three days of selling that had helped to push the index to its lowest level since December, 1998.

Similarly, the Dow Jones industrial average benefited from a typical late afternoon rush of activity, this time on the upside, allowing a gain of 82.55 points, or 0.81 per cent, to 10,290.80 by day's end.

Meanwhile, the Toronto Stock Exchange 300-stock composite index belatedly joined the party, erasing losses suffered earlier in the day to close up 29.16 points, or 0.37 per cent, at 7,959.46.

"The U.S. [indexes] closed at their highs [for the day], so it inspired the TSE to get off its butt and finally move into positive territory," said Katherine Beattie, senior technical analyst at Standard & Poor's MMS in Toronto.

"Twenty-nine points isn't a lot, but at least we closed at the high of the day. I think we will continue higher tomorrow." But she added, "it's certainly a very fragile market."

Helping to limit Monday's sudden selloff was the reluctance of mom-and-pop investors to panic and enter the fray. "A lot of people are simply waiting it out, or they are nibbling," said Paul Bates, chief executive officer of Charles Schwab Canada in Toronto.

In fact, with millions of ordinary investors staying away from the uncertain market, the price swings can become all the more erratic as much of the activity is left to traders and major players, at least one market watcher said.

"What we saw was a market that gapped downward [Monday] on little volume, and probably because investors are very much on the sidelines, that's why you get as much volatility as you do," argued Bruce Schwenger, president of Bank of Montreal's InvestorLine North America in Chicago.

The numerous negative earnings forecasts and layoff announcements yesterday, primarily in the United States, also kept ordinary investors at bay.

In a way, it's a setup that investors created themselves. Demands by regulators and investors that companies provide better public disclosure about their profit forecasts have brought not only more openness, but a barrage of profit warnings that have pummelled individual stocks in recent days.

Yesterday alone, negative corporate news and warnings of lower earnings came from companies as divergent as Kmart Corp. and Club Med. Shares of Harley-Davidson Inc. suffered after it was reported that sales rose 1.9 per cent February. Company watchers had been hoping for at least 10 per cent.

Yet the market seemed to view each bit of bad news in isolation, acting as though it may be accepting the new culture of greater openness when it comes to earnings forecasts, even if it still got spooked by negative announcements in recent weeks by such big tech names as Nortel Networks Corp. and Cisco Systems Inc.

New regulations, particularly in the United States, "have mandated full and instantaneous information in an environment where much of that information has been adverse," said Thomas Madden, chief investment officer for Federated Investors in Pittsburgh.

But the market was willing to forgive many of yesterday's announcements so long as the buying momentum continued.

Also helping improve the mood was the simple fact that many market watchers saw bargains to be had.

As Tom Galvin, New York-based market strategist at Credit Suisse First Boston, said half-jokingly yesterday, when the prices of once-high-flying stocks get so low that they're the same as your shoe size, that's when "investors have to stand up and take notice."

urn:contentItem:5RW7-WXW1-JD3N-500G-00000-00ALL CHANGE - THE FUTURE OF BANKING2018-03-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:08:51ZLexisNexisPg. 8ALL CHANGE - THE FUTURE OF BANKINGRICHARD GLUYAS

Our banks face unprecedented scrutiny from the royal commission into financial services, but that's only one of the challenges for the Big Four in a time of fragmentation and disruption

Australia's banks have had a pretty easy run of it over the past two decades. Sure, the 2008 financial crisis was an existential threat, but the key to long-term value creation for the Big Four has been an uncomplicated mix of leverage and asset growth powered by residential lending.

More recently, though, the game has started to fundamentally change. Even in a best-case scenario, the likelihood of bank mortgage books again trebling in size over the next decade is close to zero, assuming hyper-vigilant regulators were to turn a blind eye. The market growth is simply not there, and capital and liquidity are also constraints.

More importantly, once you throw in the threat from fintech and big tech (Apple, Google and Facebook, among others), a hostile political environment, and profound changes in consumer behaviour and demographics, it becomes clear that business as usual is simply not an option for the $3.5 trillion major-bank industry.

The flexibility of these massive institutions, which account for 28 per cent of the sharemarket's value, is being tested as never before. The good news for shareholders is that the majors have not been idle in the early phase of the digital revolution.

Australians now have ready access to funds at all hours of the day and night. They can get home loan approvals in under 24 hours, move money quickly and safely between accounts in real time through the new payments platform, pay for products with a simple tap of a card, smartphone, watch or even a ring on their finger, and have their investment portfolios managed by roboadvisers.

But this is nowhere near enough to ensure survival. In fact, neobank disrupters believe digital banking has barely scratched the surface.

Former National Australia Bank executive Eric Wilson, cofounder of the nation's first neo-bank, Xinja - a soon-to-open, 100 per cent digital bank designed entirely for the mobile market - reckons the try-hard banking apps built by the majors are nothing more than digitised versions of analog capabilities.

"The future of banking is not a bank delivered via a mobile phone, or a modernised Big Four bank, and it most certainly is not a pretty app flogging an existing legacy bank's products under a different brand," Wilson says. "Every banking model that currently exists in Australia will be extinct or on the critically endangered list within 10 years, and possibly as soon as five.

"It's even entirely probable that cash as we know it will be gone in 10 years in many parts of the world. Everything will change, and yet in other ways nothing will change at all."

Wilson is a firm believer in a doomsday scenario in which Xinja will thrive, but others have much more faith in the resilience of traditional banks.

Former ANZ Bank chief executive Mike Smith, now chairman of the Melbourne start-up incubator York Butter Factory, has experienced both ends of the size spectrum and believes it's wrong to assume that banks can be easily disrupted.

"Beware of the thought that they can, because banks are actually better at this stuff than you think," Smith told The Australian after his YBF appointment. "There are very few industries in the world that use technology like banks do."

Smith's warning is backed by a number of structural advantages enjoyed by the majors, notably their massive 70-80 per cent market share.

As a result of their size and scope, they benefit from lower operating and funding costs. This is reinforced by vertical and horizontal integration in some markets.

Potential challengers also have to confront the strong brand recognition and massive distribution networks of the incumbents.

In 2016, there were more than 5300 bank branches, compared with 470 for credit unions and 76 for building societies, with the majors strongly represented in alternative distribution channels such as the mortgage broking industry.

While it's true that customers increasingly prefer online channels, the physical presence of the banks helps to reinforce their muscular brands.

The problem for the banks is that these longstanding barriers to entry are starting to crumble, some of them much more rapidly than others.

For a start, consumer behaviour and attitudes are changing fast. Gen Y already makes up 22 per cent of the Australian population and will comprise half the workforce in five years.

Their priorities and preferences are fundamentally different they are rapid adopters of technology, take advice from alternative sources such as social media, and have no patience for cumbersome processes and poor service.

Loyalty to a financial institution is a thing of the past, with KPMG Australia finding last year that 28 per cent of Gen Y professionals hold financial products with three or more institutions, up from 11 per cent a year before. More worryingly, almost 60 per cent of US bank customers are willing to try a financial product from a tech giant they already use.

Younger people are even more open to the idea, with 73 per cent of people aged from 18 to 34 saying they would try a tech company's credit card, deposit account, investment or mortgage.

The message to incumbent banks is that an attractive alternative provider is only a few keystrokes away if the customer experience falls short of the one offered by an Amazon or an Airbnb. It's little wonder a sense of urgency has gripped the centuries-old banking industry.

At The Australian's Competitive Advantage Forum late last year, NAB chair Ken Henry and his Westpac counterpart Lindsay Maxsted agreed that the next wave of competition would come from outside the industry.

"The competitive challenge in our industry is not so much that one of us is going to cut the other's throat. It's not that," Henry said. "It's that we are going to be challenged beyond our ability to cope by the big IT platform providers, the Googles and the Apples and so on."

The race is on to act smaller, simpler and be more focused, with the Melbourne majors more vocal about the scale of their ambitions than the big Sydney mortgage banks.

Last August, the chief executive of ANZ Bank, Shayne Elliott, unveiled The ANZ Way, a workplace revolution that mimics successful tech companies such as Spotify and Netflix by shaking up cumbersome, bureaucratic processes and adopting an agile approach.

NAB, for its part, said in November it would cut 6000 jobs, or 18 per cent of its workforce, in three years, while hiring 2000 people with specialist skills for the digital age. The bank wants to build an army of workers skilled in data science, artificial intelligence, robotics and automation.

Similar programs have been launched at Commonwealth Bank and Westpac, albeit with less fanfare, as the entire sector is swept along in a digital fervour.

At Commonwealth Bank, 56 per cent of all transactions by value are now digital, up from 47 per cent in mid-2014, with product sales through digital channels spiking from 11 per cent to 29 per cent over the same period.

Weekly logons to the CommBank app have trebled to 30 million, underpinning $6.1 billion in transactions per week, up from $1.5 billion, while the number of tap and go transactions per quarter has surged from 600,000 to 3.7 million.

Simplification has become a buzzword as the banks sell peripheral assets, dramatically cut the number of IT applications and rationalise their product portfolios.

NAB, for example, will have 50 per cent fewer products in three years. Elliott has reinforced the message to his dwindling workforce, stressing that getting things done at ANZ can sometimes be "really hard".

"Too often we are slow, bureaucratic or we over-complicate things that should be simple," he says.

The burning question is whether this blizzard of activity is going to be enough to allow traditional banks to survive, let alone prosper.

Peering 20 years into the future, ANZ digital boss Maile Carnegie said in a recent interview with The Australian that she expects to see two major banks instead of the current four, a tech giant or two in the form of an Apple, Google or Amazon, and a handful of fintech companies that have somehow built the stamina and support to last the journey.

It's a scenario that contemplates a complete upending of the status quo. Momentum for change will start to accelerate once constraints on the power of consumer choice are lifted.

In a January draft report on competition in the Australian financial system, the Productivity Commission said planned reforms such as open banking, which enables consumers to transfer their data from one provider to another, would provide a powerful spur to competition.

The PC said the vast majority of financial institutions are using tactics designed to lure new customers and then retain them by exploiting the system's complexity.

Blockchain also looms as an extremely disruptive technology. Conceived as the structural underpinning of the cryptocurrency Bitcoin, the blockchain is easier to imagine as a kind of digital ledger - a spreadsheet that records transactions, agreements, or anything that needs to be independently recorded and verified.

The big difference is that the ledger is not stored in a single place; it can be distributed across a handful or even thousands of computers around the world. When someone transfers Bitcoin, the transaction is verified by the system, encrypted, and a new line, or "block", is added to the spreadsheet.

Despite Bitcoin's wild volatility, International Monetary Fund boss Christine Lagarde says that it "may not be wise to dismiss virtual currencies".

If she is right and cryptocurrencies powered by blockchain do take hold, then the financial system starts to look like a very different place.

"It's a world where client data is instantly portable [through open banking], there is no need for a trusted third party to hold your cash [because of cryptocurrencies], no need to pay a clip on transactions [because of the blockchain], and most critically, it's a world where a loan rate can be arbitraged quickly and efficiently," Xinja's Wilson says.

"There will be major and powerful disruption in the Australian banking industry in the coming years. People will lose their jobs and iconic brands will fade away, but consumers will get better services at much lower prices."

The vision is one where customers are empowered at the expense of institutions, taking control over their data and exercising choice.

Banks will wither unless they find ways of adding genuine value, because the current approach of selling products and charging fees will not be sustainable.

In their place, according to Wilson, will be something more like the bank manager of old - a respected figure who guides customers to better decisions and outcomes.

"But not a physical being," he prophesies. "Perhaps not 'someone' but 'some bot'."

Richard Gluyas is The Australian's senior business correspondent
