JASON CHAFFETZ, FOX NEWS HOST: Shannon Bream and the "FOX NEWS @ NIGHT" team take it from here. It's been an honor and a privilege to guest host tonight. But stay tuned for Shannon Bream's show. You're going to love it. Thank you again.

SHANNON BREAM, FOX NEWS ANCHOR: This is a Fox News alert. This could have been preventable. Those words from a grieving California sheriff after an officer was gunned down in cold blood. The sheriff says, by an illegal alien, running from a drunk driving stop. The sheriff putting part of the blame on California's sanctuary policies.

Democratic leader Nancy Pelosi reportedly enjoying the big island of Hawaii amid the partial government shutdown in the battle over border security. She's not alone in escaping the beltway but could lawmakers actually get something done since the president is here and he says he's waiting on them? We'll debate.

And there's a fight over religious liberty and LGBTQ rights over controversial nominee to the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission. She claims she's being unfairly targeted and misquoted. A Republican senator says she's against religious liberty. Tony Perkins from the Family Research Council will weigh in.

Hello and welcome to FOX NEWS @ NIGHT. I'm Shannon Bream in Washington. We begin with a tragedy sparking a national debate. In simmering battles over sanctuary cities and border security. Chief correspondent Jonathan Hunt joins us now from Los Angeles. Hey, Jonathan.

JONATHAN HUNT, FOX NEWS CHIEF CORRESPONDENT: Good evening, Shannon. The alleged killer of Ronil Singh was apparently trying to make a run for Mexico. But officers, aided by aerial surveillance, swept into arrest him in Bakersfield, that's in central California, some 200 miles south of where the shooting happened. The arrest came just 48 hours after 33-year-old officer Ronil Singh was gunned down. He leaves behind his wife and 5- month-old son.

Today, officer Singh's brother broke down as he thanked police and sheriff deputies for finding the suspect.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REGGIE SINGH, OFFICER RONIL SINGH'S BROTHER: There's a lot of people out there that misses him, and a lot of law enforcement people that I don't know that work days and nights to make this happen. I'd like to thank you from the bottom of my heart.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

HUNT: The suspect, Gustavo Perez Arriaga, was in the U.S. illegally, according to the local sheriff, who angrily denounced California's so- called sanctuary laws, which the sheriff said prevented Perez Arriaga from being deported for previous DUI convictions.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ADAM CHRISTIANSON, SHERIFF, STANISLAUS COUNTY, CALIFORNIA: This is a criminal illegal alien with prior criminal activity that should have been reported to ICE. We were prohibited, law enforcement was prohibited because of sanctuary laws and that led to the encounter with Officer Singh.

I'm suggesting that the outcome could have been different if law enforcement wasn't restricted, prohibited, or had their hands tied because of political interference.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

HUNT: Officer Singh was shot dead around 1:00 a.m. Wednesday morning after stopping a driver on suspicion of DUI. Moments later, he radioed, "Shots fired. I've been hit." He was a legal immigrant who had come to the U.S. from Fiji where he was born. He studied criminal justice once he got here, and spent 12 years in law enforcement, seven of those with the Newman Police Department.

He even took and paid for extra English lessons to help make himself better understood by his colleagues. The Newman Police Department, by the way, Shannon, has just 12 officers. A close-knit family, and the words of the police chief, and a family that will never forget Ronil Singh. Shannon?

BREAM: Well, Jonathan, they got their suspects. We'll watch this case very closely. Thank you very much.

Homeland security secretary, Kirstjen Nielsen is in El Paso, Texas, where an 8-year-old Guatemalan boy was detained with his father before dying in government custody after two hospital visits. Nielsen touring multiple stations and substations operated by customs and border protection and meeting with the MTs and other first responders. Nielsen is scheduled to move onto Yuma, Arizona, tomorrow.

Well, judging from his tweets, President Trump is keeping a close eye on the border as he stays here in D.C., again this weekend. Though nearly all lawmakers are out of town, amidst this partial government shutdown. Rich Edson joins us now for the latest from the White House and the big island of Hawaii.

RICH EDSON, FOX NEWS WASHINGTON CORRESPONDENT: That's right. Too bad I'm not going live from there.

BREAM: I know.

EDSON: But we'll make do with this.

BREAM: Thanks for being with us though.

EDSON: Pleasure to be here.

So, you know, Shannon, there is no indication as partial government shutdown ends this year. Congress is mostly out of town. President Trump is still here, tweeting, quote, "We will be forced to close the southern border entirely if the obstructionist Democrats do not give us the money to finish the wall and also change the ridiculous immigration laws that our country is saddled with. Hard to believe there was a Congress and president who would approve."

The president is also threatening again to cut aid to Honduras, Guatemala, and El Salvador, for failing to prevent their citizens from traveling illegally to the U.S. border.

The White House and Democrats are a few billion dollars apart on funding for border security. President Trump insists on money for a wall, house Democrats say the president's wall proposal is immoral, ineffective, and expensive.

Republicans are now trying to pin shutdown blame on House Democratic leader Nancy Pelosi saying she's refusing to negotiate on wall funding to appear to liberal House Democrats and to assure their support in her race for speaker.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MICK MULVANEY, ACTING WHITE HOUSE CHIEF OF STAFF: She does not have the votes and if she cuts a deal with the president, of any sort before her election on January 3rd, she's at risk of losing her speakership. So we're in this for the long haul.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

EDSON: Republicans are also pointing to a story published in the Washington Free Beacon, claiming Pelosi is spending the shutdown vacationing at a luxury resort in Hawaii. Pelosi's office has refused to confirm or deny this story.

Our Capitol Hill team says leaders from both parties haven't been seen lately on Capitol Hill.

Republicans say Democrats have shutdown negotiations, Democrats say the shut down should have never happened. New York congressman and Democratic caucus chairman, Hakeem Jeffries tweets, quote, "Day seven of the Trump shutdown, Republicans continue to hold the American people hostage. We refuse to pay $5 billion ransom note, in other words, take a hike."

Congressional leaders say they'll give members at least 24 hours notice to return to Washington to vote on any agreement to fund the government. Shannon?

BREAM: Unlikely before next Thursday. But we're all be ready if it happens. Thanks, Rich.

All right. Let's bring in tonight's "Power Panel." Fox news contributor, Jehmu Greene. Border Patrol Council vice president, Art Del Cueto. And Fox News political analyst, Gianno Caldwell. Welcome to all of you.

JEHMU GREENE, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Good evening.

BREAM: OK. I want to play a little bit more of what the sheriff had today -- to say today about the fact that California has a sanctuary state policies and it makes his job tougher. Here's what he said.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CHRISTIANSON: Suggesting that the outcome could have been different if law enforcement wasn't restricted, prohibited, or had their hands tied because of political interference.

Why are we providing sanctuary for criminals? Gang members. It's a conversation we need to have.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BREAM: Jehmu, your reaction?

GREENE: Well, first, and definitely foremost, you think about the family and prayers go out to the family, to the community. And it's really important I think in these times that you don't use a crime like this to demonize all undocumented immigrants.

We want this murderer to have justice that is swift and harsh. But that certainly does not mean that there is link of criminality to the rest of undocumented immigrants, as some --

BREAM: And I don't think anyone is making that suggestion.

GIANNO CALDWELL, FOX NEWS POLITICAL ANALYST: No one's heard that. Where did that come from?

GREENE: Many Republicans want that to be the case, when the reality is, undocumented immigrants in this country commit considerably less crimes. Considerably less crimes than native born --

BREAM: But what we're talking about is this one situation where apparently, according to the law enforcement officials involved that this man should not have been in the country. He had previous DUI arrests. That he came here illegally.

So in the case of this family and this slain officer, Gianno, we're talking about somebody that potentially, the state's on policies allowed this or cases like this, to happen.

CALDWELL: Yes. I'm incredibly disappointed with my dear colleague Jehmu's rhetoric on this issue. This is a safety issue plain and simple. It's not a partisan issue. If you look at the pure numbers, 74 percent of individuals that were brought in by ICE. In 2017, had previous felony convictions.

We talk about the sanctuary city status of places like Chicago and the state of California, which don't provide any funding for those that may be -- that ICE may want to retain. They may want to detain those individuals. They can use any personnel for that.

So, yes, this is making our country less safe and certainly, this is something that I said two days ago, on this very network, that Democrats are going to have to own any criminality that's perpetrated by individuals. They came into this country illegally because they refused to negotiate what the president of the United States on border security.

So when you have a Congress, a democratic caucus who refused to negotiate, when you have local elected officials who refused to follow the trend of -- if individuals are coming over here illegally and they are doing illegal activities that could possibly harm U.S. citizens, like we just saw, that they don't -- they don't buy into that.

So this is as very problematic. And, Jehmu, I'm just so surprised and disappointed with what you said. I'm sorry.

GREENE: Well, Shannon, there's the link right there that Gianno is trying to make between criminality and undocumented immigrants, that is just not - -

CALDWELL: I never said that.

(CROSSTALK)

BREAM: Let me bring Art in here. Because what we're talking about is -- we're talking about -- we're talking about this case and what clearly happened here.

Now, Art, a lot of folks would say, both parties bear the blame. Both of them have been in control, at some point, the White House, the Senate, and House, and have not gotten this fixed. You know firsthand what's going on at the border.

DHS Secretary Nielsen is there today to see for herself. She's been there many times before. But Congress, it's up to them to fix this, regardless of which party is in control, they don't seem to be able to get it done.

ART DEL CUETO, VICE PRESIDENT, NATIONAL BORDER PATROL COUNCIL: Being an illegal in this country and the security of our nation's border has nothing to do with what political party you are in. First and foremost.

Now, this is a horrific, horrific incident that happened with this officer dying, and it is 100 percent because of sanctuary cities. It is 100 percent because what you do when you have these sanctuary cities is you create a magnet for these individuals that like to break the law, which, just by the fact that you're illegally in this country, you're already a criminal, plain and simple.

People say, oh, well, he's just illegally in the country, he's not a criminal. No. If he's illegally in the country, that makes him a criminal. And it is definitely at the hands of any single individual, politician, or whoever that maybe that supports sanctuary cities.

BREAM: All right. So, Jehmu, where do we go from here? I mean, the Democrats take over the House in January, just a week from now and they've said the first thing they're going to do is refund the government, they're not going to have any funding for the wall, so that's going to go to the Senate. If it makes it through their, to the president, he said he's not going to sign anything that doesn't have funding for the wall.

I mean, where does this standoff end?

GREENE: Well, I think one place we could go from here is to revisit some of the policies that we saw in the Obama administration that were very much focused on criminals that were here undocumented, and how to put in smarter policies to target them, to track them, to find them, and to get them out of the country. When we look at how this administration is dealing with immigration and throwing out mothers who have been here for 20 years with no criminal record, and anyone who they come in contact with, that takes away the focus.

DEL CUETO: They're here illegally. That's (INAUDIBLE) all on its own.

GREENE: And so, yes, it would be -- it would be better to focus on those criminals and get them out.

BREAM: Art, I know you had something to say there. I mean, this is part of what you do and being a part of border patrol. I mean, you've seen this firsthand. What's the reality? Because listen, we know under the Obama administration, he became known as the Deporter in Chief because they were turning around so many people.

It wasn't a positive to a lot of people who supported President Obama, but we know that these policies of turning people back of denying asylum claims. I mean, they aren't new. Why are they reported and treated differently now?

DEL CUETO: Because these people care more about being angry at the president than they do about the United States and the American citizens. That's what it is. That's the way I see it.

Look, I have skin in the game. I'm out there in the field. I'm out there arresting some of these individuals, and it's easy to Monday morning quarterback it, you know, behind a desk, and you know, Far East. It's easy to Monday morning quarterback it.

JASON CHAFFETZ, FOX NEWS HOST: Shannon Bream and the "FOX NEWS @ NIGHT" team take it from here. It's been an honor and a privilege to guest host tonight. But stay tuned for Shannon Bream's show. You're going to love it. Thank you again.

SHANNON BREAM, FOX NEWS ANCHOR: This is a Fox News alert. This could have been preventable. Those words from a grieving California sheriff after an officer was gunned down in cold blood. The sheriff says, by an illegal alien, running from a drunk driving stop. The sheriff putting part of the blame on California's sanctuary policies.

Democratic leader Nancy Pelosi reportedly enjoying the big island of Hawaii amid the partial government shutdown in the battle over border security. She's not alone in escaping the beltway but could lawmakers actually get something done since the president is here and he says he's waiting on them? We'll debate.

And there's a fight over religious liberty and LGBTQ rights over controversial nominee to the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission. She claims she's being unfairly targeted and misquoted. A Republican senator says she's against religious liberty. Tony Perkins from the Family Research Council will weigh in.

Hello and welcome to FOX NEWS @ NIGHT. I'm Shannon Bream in Washington. We begin with a tragedy sparking a national debate. In simmering battles over sanctuary cities and border security. Chief correspondent Jonathan Hunt joins us now from Los Angeles. Hey, Jonathan.

JONATHAN HUNT, FOX NEWS CHIEF CORRESPONDENT: Good evening, Shannon. The alleged killer of Ronil Singh was apparently trying to make a run for Mexico. But officers, aided by aerial surveillance, swept into arrest him in Bakersfield, that's in central California, some 200 miles south of where the shooting happened. The arrest came just 48 hours after 33-year-old officer Ronil Singh was gunned down. He leaves behind his wife and 5- month-old son.

Today, officer Singh's brother broke down as he thanked police and sheriff deputies for finding the suspect.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REGGIE SINGH, OFFICER RONIL SINGH'S BROTHER: There's a lot of people out there that misses him, and a lot of law enforcement people that I don't know that work days and nights to make this happen. I'd like to thank you from the bottom of my heart.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

HUNT: The suspect, Gustavo Perez Arriaga, was in the U.S. illegally, according to the local sheriff, who angrily denounced California's so- called sanctuary laws, which the sheriff said prevented Perez Arriaga from being deported for previous DUI convictions.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ADAM CHRISTIANSON, SHERIFF, STANISLAUS COUNTY, CALIFORNIA: This is a criminal illegal alien with prior criminal activity that should have been reported to ICE. We were prohibited, law enforcement was prohibited because of sanctuary laws and that led to the encounter with Officer Singh.

I'm suggesting that the outcome could have been different if law enforcement wasn't restricted, prohibited, or had their hands tied because of political interference.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

HUNT: Officer Singh was shot dead around 1:00 a.m. Wednesday morning after stopping a driver on suspicion of DUI. Moments later, he radioed, "Shots fired. I've been hit." He was a legal immigrant who had come to the U.S. from Fiji where he was born. He studied criminal justice once he got here, and spent 12 years in law enforcement, seven of those with the Newman Police Department.

He even took and paid for extra English lessons to help make himself better understood by his colleagues. The Newman Police Department, by the way, Shannon, has just 12 officers. A close-knit family, and the words of the police chief, and a family that will never forget Ronil Singh. Shannon?

BREAM: Well, Jonathan, they got their suspects. We'll watch this case very closely. Thank you very much.

Homeland security secretary, Kirstjen Nielsen is in El Paso, Texas, where an 8-year-old Guatemalan boy was detained with his father before dying in government custody after two hospital visits. Nielsen touring multiple stations and substations operated by customs and border protection and meeting with the MTs and other first responders. Nielsen is scheduled to move onto Yuma, Arizona, tomorrow.

Well, judging from his tweets, President Trump is keeping a close eye on the border as he stays here in D.C., again this weekend. Though nearly all lawmakers are out of town, amidst this partial government shutdown. Rich Edson joins us now for the latest from the White House and the big island of Hawaii.

RICH EDSON, FOX NEWS WASHINGTON CORRESPONDENT: That's right. Too bad I'm not going live from there.

BREAM: I know.

EDSON: But we'll make do with this.

BREAM: Thanks for being with us though.

EDSON: Pleasure to be here.

So, you know, Shannon, there is no indication as partial government shutdown ends this year. Congress is mostly out of town. President Trump is still here, tweeting, quote, "We will be forced to close the southern border entirely if the obstructionist Democrats do not give us the money to finish the wall and also change the ridiculous immigration laws that our country is saddled with. Hard to believe there was a Congress and president who would approve."

The president is also threatening again to cut aid to Honduras, Guatemala, and El Salvador, for failing to prevent their citizens from traveling illegally to the U.S. border.

The White House and Democrats are a few billion dollars apart on funding for border security. President Trump insists on money for a wall, house Democrats say the president's wall proposal is immoral, ineffective, and expensive.

Republicans are now trying to pin shutdown blame on House Democratic leader Nancy Pelosi saying she's refusing to negotiate on wall funding to appear to liberal House Democrats and to assure their support in her race for speaker.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MICK MULVANEY, ACTING WHITE HOUSE CHIEF OF STAFF: She does not have the votes and if she cuts a deal with the president, of any sort before her election on January 3rd, she's at risk of losing her speakership. So we're in this for the long haul.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

EDSON: Republicans are also pointing to a story published in the Washington Free Beacon, claiming Pelosi is spending the shutdown vacationing at a luxury resort in Hawaii. Pelosi's office has refused to confirm or deny this story.

Our Capitol Hill team says leaders from both parties haven't been seen lately on Capitol Hill.

Republicans say Democrats have shutdown negotiations, Democrats say the shut down should have never happened. New York congressman and Democratic caucus chairman, Hakeem Jeffries tweets, quote, "Day seven of the Trump shutdown, Republicans continue to hold the American people hostage. We refuse to pay $5 billion ransom note, in other words, take a hike."

Congressional leaders say they'll give members at least 24 hours notice to return to Washington to vote on any agreement to fund the government. Shannon?

BREAM: Unlikely before next Thursday. But we're all be ready if it happens. Thanks, Rich.

All right. Let's bring in tonight's "Power Panel." Fox news contributor, Jehmu Greene. Border Patrol Council vice president, Art Del Cueto. And Fox News political analyst, Gianno Caldwell. Welcome to all of you.

JEHMU GREENE, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Good evening.

BREAM: OK. I want to play a little bit more of what the sheriff had today -- to say today about the fact that California has a sanctuary state policies and it makes his job tougher. Here's what he said.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CHRISTIANSON: Suggesting that the outcome could have been different if law enforcement wasn't restricted, prohibited, or had their hands tied because of political interference.

Why are we providing sanctuary for criminals? Gang members. It's a conversation we need to have.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BREAM: Jehmu, your reaction?

GREENE: Well, first, and definitely foremost, you think about the family and prayers go out to the family, to the community. And it's really important I think in these times that you don't use a crime like this to demonize all undocumented immigrants.

We want this murderer to have justice that is swift and harsh. But that certainly does not mean that there is link of criminality to the rest of undocumented immigrants, as some --

BREAM: And I don't think anyone is making that suggestion.

GIANNO CALDWELL, FOX NEWS POLITICAL ANALYST: No one's heard that. Where did that come from?

GREENE: Many Republicans want that to be the case, when the reality is, undocumented immigrants in this country commit considerably less crimes. Considerably less crimes than native born --

BREAM: But what we're talking about is this one situation where apparently, according to the law enforcement officials involved that this man should not have been in the country. He had previous DUI arrests. That he came here illegally.

So in the case of this family and this slain officer, Gianno, we're talking about somebody that potentially, the state's on policies allowed this or cases like this, to happen.

CALDWELL: Yes. I'm incredibly disappointed with my dear colleague Jehmu's rhetoric on this issue. This is a safety issue plain and simple. It's not a partisan issue. If you look at the pure numbers, 74 percent of individuals that were brought in by ICE. In 2017, had previous felony convictions.

We talk about the sanctuary city status of places like Chicago and the state of California, which don't provide any funding for those that may be -- that ICE may want to retain. They may want to detain those individuals. They can use any personnel for that.

So, yes, this is making our country less safe and certainly, this is something that I said two days ago, on this very network, that Democrats are going to have to own any criminality that's perpetrated by individuals. They came into this country illegally because they refused to negotiate what the president of the United States on border security.

So when you have a Congress, a democratic caucus who refused to negotiate, when you have local elected officials who refused to follow the trend of -- if individuals are coming over here illegally and they are doing illegal activities that could possibly harm U.S. citizens, like we just saw, that they don't -- they don't buy into that.

So this is as very problematic. And, Jehmu, I'm just so surprised and disappointed with what you said. I'm sorry.

GREENE: Well, Shannon, there's the link right there that Gianno is trying to make between criminality and undocumented immigrants, that is just not - -

CALDWELL: I never said that.

(CROSSTALK)

BREAM: Let me bring Art in here. Because what we're talking about is -- we're talking about -- we're talking about this case and what clearly happened here.

Now, Art, a lot of folks would say, both parties bear the blame. Both of them have been in control, at some point, the White House, the Senate, and House, and have not gotten this fixed. You know firsthand what's going on at the border.

DHS Secretary Nielsen is there today to see for herself. She's been there many times before. But Congress, it's up to them to fix this, regardless of which party is in control, they don't seem to be able to get it done.

ART DEL CUETO, VICE PRESIDENT, NATIONAL BORDER PATROL COUNCIL: Being an illegal in this country and the security of our nation's border has nothing to do with what political party you are in. First and foremost.

Now, this is a horrific, horrific incident that happened with this officer dying, and it is 100 percent because of sanctuary cities. It is 100 percent because what you do when you have these sanctuary cities is you create a magnet for these individuals that like to break the law, which, just by the fact that you're illegally in this country, you're already a criminal, plain and simple.

People say, oh, well, he's just illegally in the country, he's not a criminal. No. If he's illegally in the country, that makes him a criminal. And it is definitely at the hands of any single individual, politician, or whoever that maybe that supports sanctuary cities.

BREAM: All right. So, Jehmu, where do we go from here? I mean, the Democrats take over the House in January, just a week from now and they've said the first thing they're going to do is refund the government, they're not going to have any funding for the wall, so that's going to go to the Senate. If it makes it through their, to the president, he said he's not going to sign anything that doesn't have funding for the wall.

I mean, where does this standoff end?

GREENE: Well, I think one place we could go from here is to revisit some of the policies that we saw in the Obama administration that were very much focused on criminals that were here undocumented, and how to put in smarter policies to target them, to track them, to find them, and to get them out of the country. When we look at how this administration is dealing with immigration and throwing out mothers who have been here for 20 years with no criminal record, and anyone who they come in contact with, that takes away the focus.

DEL CUETO: They're here illegally. That's (INAUDIBLE) all on its own.

GREENE: And so, yes, it would be -- it would be better to focus on those criminals and get them out.

BREAM: Art, I know you had something to say there. I mean, this is part of what you do and being a part of border patrol. I mean, you've seen this firsthand. What's the reality? Because listen, we know under the Obama administration, he became known as the Deporter in Chief because they were turning around so many people.

It wasn't a positive to a lot of people who supported President Obama, but we know that these policies of turning people back of denying asylum claims. I mean, they aren't new. Why are they reported and treated differently now?

DEL CUETO: Because these people care more about being angry at the president than they do about the United States and the American citizens. That's what it is. That's the way I see it.

Look, I have skin in the game. I'm out there in the field. I'm out there arresting some of these individuals, and it's easy to Monday morning quarterback it, you know, behind a desk, and you know, Far East. It's easy to Monday morning quarterback it.

President Trump has done everything possible to make sure that this country moves forward and that there's border security. And that's the reality of the entire situation.

He's a president that has reached out to the National Border Patrol council. He's on point with everything he says. And everyone needs to get on the same page because it's getting frustrating to see so many people that really don't care about the American public or about our borders, about border security.

And even with the shutdown. I have skin in the game, as I said before. We don't know when or if our next paycheck is going to come. And I've been misquoted and some of the media, or some of my words have been twisted. And I can tell you right now, the National Border Patrol Council, which I am a part of, fully support the president and fully support the shutdown, if that's what the president is asking for.

BREAM: All right. Gianno, I want to --

CALDWELL: If I can really quickly jump in there. I know that you -- really quickly.

BREAM: Sure. Go ahead.

CALDWELL: So to your same question to him, the reason why we see like nothing being done, I think Democrats have seen, especially some of our Latino brothers and sisters that are coming in, as a power base for them.

So we think about in 2006 when Senator Barack Obama said on the floor of the Senate that we needed the Secure Fence Act, which 26 Democrats voted in favor of it. Hillary Clinton, Chuck Schumer himself, they talked about border security in a positive way back then.

But now that we see that there is an influx and now Latinos are going to be the new minority, the new major minority, I think they're seeing this as a potential power block for them so they might as well support anything that's going to keep these voters happy.

GREENE: That is so false. That is so false and unfair.

BREAM: Gianno, the Republicans have control of the White House, the House and Senate for the last two years and their base wants to know why they didn't get something done.

CALDWELL: And that -- and that's a -- that's a very good question. I think we didn't have enough votes in the Senate to actually get something passed. Similar to that, you have to work with Democrats on it. Think about what President Trump offered the deal in terms of DACA. Democrats didn't even take it, they didn't want to take it off the table because they wanted to keep the issue alive for the midterm elections and that's exactly what they did.

(CROSSTALK)

GREENE: Jehmu, the President keeps reneging on his deals. First it was $1.3 billion for a wall, then it's $2.5 billion for a wall. With DACA, he's reneged on so many deals. If this President is about making deals, you have to be a man of your word. He sent Vice President Pence out to front for him and then reneged on that deal. How can you get to a place of compromise and understanding if the President can't even keep his word on this issue?

BREAM: Well, he's -- listen, he's asked for a lot more than that. He and now several others in the White House say they are offering compromise deals, they've heard nothing back and don't expect they will from the Democrats until Nancy Pelosi is Speaker. So one week from today, maybe we'll have this conversation again and see if the government is reopened or what's happening. In the meantime, Jehmu, Art, and Gianno, thank you, all. Appreciate your time.

CALDWELL: Thank you.

GREENE: Thanks.

DEL CUETO: Thank you for having me.

BREAM: All right. The Florida Sun Sentinel publishing a bombshell report tonight on the Parkland School shooting massacre in February this year. It's headline this, unprepared and overwhelmed. The paper goes on to report the two decades after Columbine at five years after Sandy Hook, educators and police still weren't ready for Parkland. Surveillance video and the reports shows the killer Nikolas Cruz in the beginning moments of the massacre telling another student, "you better get out of here, things are going to get messy."

And pulls out the AR-15 and begins shooting. The video also shows Deputy Scott Peterson, the school resource officer, the only armed law man on the campus as he reportedly -- the paper says, failed to go inside the building despite shots being fired. He ordered a school lockdown instead of ordering deputies toward the building. Later revealed in this report that officers "may rush toward gunfire rather than shout" according to policy there in Broward County.

Well, pushback on one of President Trump's nominees to a key federal agency by a member of his own party. We're going to tell you why. Senator Mike Lee is trying to block the nominee because of what he says is a religious freedom issue. And Tony Perkins, president of the research -- Family Research Council joins and he's going to weigh in on why this nominee is so controversial.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BREAM: Republican Senator Mike Lee is taking a stand against one of President Trump's nominees to a key Federal agency. The controversy is pretty much flown under the radar in the middle of the government shutdown but for the right and the left, there are some big issues at stake here from traditional marriage to workplace discrimination. Correspondent David Spunt is here to tell us why Senator Lee is blocking his own president -- his own party's nominee.

DAVID SPUNT, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Yes. Shannon, it's a quite a story. As you know, the EEOC is there to protect people's civil rights in the workplace and Chai Feldblum, she's not new to the agency. She's been a commissioner since 2010, receiving support from both Republicans and Democrats. In fact, President Trump renominated her to her post just a year ago. Tonight she's defending her name as Senator Lee says, he'll really do whatever he can do to make sure that she is out of a job.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

SEN. MIKE LEE (R), UTAH: I object to her confirmation.

SPUNT: Utah Senator Mike Lee is making it clear he wants EEOC Commissioner Chai Feldblum out over concerns about her stance on religious liberty. He is prepared for a fight.

LEE: The Federal government should never, Mr. President, be used as a tool to stamp out religious liberty. That principle is so central to our nation's founding and human happiness itself. It's so important that we've got to stand behind it. Mrs. Feldblum, however, wants to deny exactly that.

SPUNT: Feldblum is the first and only openly gay EEOC commissioner who was quoted in a 2006 article as saying she had difficult time finding any case in which religious liberty should win over sexual liberty. Feldblum claims she was misquoted, and put out this written statement over lee's position. Senator Lee and others may feel they have kept a rabid opponent to religious liberty off the equal employment opportunity commission.

They are wrong. It is true that they have ensured that someone who cares deeply about both religious liberty and LGBT rights won't protecting those interests from the perch of the EEOC. But I have fought from the civil rights for LGBT people, religious people, and others for years. I won't be stopping now. Feldblum went on to tell Fox News in an e-mail, Senator Lee refused to meet with me when I asked to do so.

Perhaps that is why he does not know what I actually believe. In 2009, Feldblum defended religious liberty.

CHAI FELDBLUM, COMMISSIONER, EQUAL EMPLOYMENT OPPORTUNITY COMMISSION: I also have a deep respect for and understanding of religious practice, and a deep-seated tolerance for religious difference.

SPUNT: Washington Democrat Senator Patty Murray says Feldblum must be confirmed for the sake of millions of employees across the country.

SEN. PATTY MURRAY (D), WASHINGTON: Because of the objection of a single Republican Senator, it is possible now that the EEOC will be unable to deduct some of its most critical work.

SPUNT: But Lee says he'll continue to fight to protect religious liberty, a concept he believes the EEOC should welcome.

LEE: Who is she to decide whether or not someone should be permitted to persist in their own religious beliefs? Simply because those beliefs happen to conflict with a particular political worldview?

(END VIDEOTAPE)

SPUNT: And speaking of religious beliefs and an e-mail tonight, Feldblum told me that her late father was a proud rabbi. Shannon, he said -- she said he would be very upset to see exactly the way she is being portrayed right now in the media. Especially by Senator Lee with this whole situation going on.

BREAM: All right. Well, we'll keep an eye on it because I guess her commission essentially expires New Year's eve if the Senate doesn't do something and they're not here, so --

SPUNT: They're not here and there's a lot of questions about how the EEOC is going to operate for those millions of people around the country if she is not in.

BREAM: All right. David, thank you.

SPUNT: You bet.

BREAM: OK. Joining us now, Tony Perkins, president of the Family Research Council to talk about this. Tony, welcome.

TONY PERKINS, PRESIDENT, FAMILY RESEARCH COUNCIL: Thanks, Shannon. Good to be with you.

BREAM: All right. I want to play a little bit more of Senator Lee's critique. And then some response from the Ms. Feldblum. So here is the Senator.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

LEE: Ms. Feldblum has written that she sees a conflict between religious belief and LGBT liberty as "a zero-sum game," where "a gain for one side necessarily entails a corresponding loss for the other side." I see no reason why that should be the case, and I think that's fundamentally incompatible with our nation's long tradition of pluralism and religious freedom.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BREAM: OK. So, Tony, here is her response. In part she says, it's an out of context quote that suggests I believe there is a zero-sum game between religious liberty and LGBT rights. And that LGBT rights must always prevail no matter what, that is not my position, and never has been. I care deeply about preserving religious pluralism in our country even if that means protecting religious organizations whose views I disagree with. That is the point of pluralism.

OK. What is getting lost in translation here?

PERKINS: Well, I think we've got to put it into context first and I know Chai Feldblum. She actually -- she actually spoke at the Family Research Council. I invited her one to come and speak on the panel and she made comments reflecting this coming collision between religious freedom and sexual liberty. And she then suggested that she saw that religious liberty would lose.

But she is also the architect of the Employment Non-Discrimination Act, which Congress has repeatedly refused to pass. Now this is -- this is literally sacrificing our vibrant first amendment on the altar of sexual libertinism. And she was unable to get that through Congress. So Barack Obama appointed her to the EEOC. Couldn't got her -- actually get her through the Senate when Harry Reid was the majority leader so he did a recess appointment.

She was subsequently after Harry Reid changed the rules where only a majority were need for presidential nominees, so she's been controversial even to her own party. She has taken positions that are 180 degrees from the Trump administration when it comes to religious freedom. And so it is -- I applaud Senator Mike Lee, spoken with him a number of times about this particular case and I applaud him for taking a stand in defense of religious liberty.

She reflects an era of the past, the Barack Obama era of hostility toward religious freedom. We don't need her on the EEOC leading that commission forward.

BREAM: But Tony, you know how this works obviously. I mean, the President has the opportunity to appoint members, the majority of members, three to two, so you have five members of the EEOC that represent his majority party but he goes to the Democrats for their nominations and their suggestions on the other two members. She is already a current sitting member of the commission.

So he's basically following up with what the Democrats want which is to keep her there. Now there is this issue as we talk about with David, that her commission expires December 31st. If the Senate doesn't take action clearly it doesn't appear that there is any way they're going to. Mitch McConnell, the Senate Majority Leader, could force a vote. Here is what a statement from (INAUDIBLE) vice president.

Here's what they say. Americans need a fully functional EEOC to combat discrimination and sexual harassment in the workplace. And Mike Lee's anti-LGBTQ views should not stand in the ways of those seeking justice under the law. Majority Leader Mitch McConnell should abide by set President and immediately hold a full Senate vote on the EEOC nominees were fair-minded voices will prevail. Do you McConnell is going to do that?

PERKINS: No, I don't. I don't think he should. First off, we have to look at what the advantage she has as a returning member of the commission. I served on the Federal Commission, I know those existing members kind of influence the new members. But you have to consider the EEOC is actually lined up in Federal court against the Trump administration's own Department of Justice on the redefinition of terms such as sexual discrimination, what sex means.

Where -- this is furthering the lawlessness of the Obama administration where they unilaterally change the terms of the 1964 antidiscrimination law and civil rights law and the 1974 title VII as it pertains to employment. They have just unilaterally redefined those terms. She's doing that by bureaucratic fiat. So I think Mitch McConnell would be wrong to move forward with this. I think Mike Lee is taking the right position. I don't think the President really is pushing this.

I think you're right. It was giving the Democrats -- somebody in the White House said let's just give him what they want. Chuck Schumer wanted her. I think she needs to be off the commission.

BREAM: Well, having practiced labor and employment law in the past, I know exactly how much power the EEOC wields. And, you know, you have to ask questions about Congress, about how much power has been delegated to these Federal agencies because they don't answer to the people, they're unelected and they do have quite a bit of power. So, we'll keep an eye on it, we'll track it and we'll have Senator Lee here in the New Year to come talk to us about it as well. Tony, thank you very much. Happy New Year.

PERKINS: Happy New Year, Shannon.

BREAM: All right. Up next, big tech is in the crosshairs. Congress expected her face off against social media prepping new regulations and potential oversight on content and privacy when lawmakers get back in the New Year.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: We have to put some rules of the road in place. We - - they can't just say, hey, trust us, we got your back.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BREAM: Plus, a look back at the winners and losers on Capitol Hill. Congress' 2018 year in review. Chad Pergram's by the numbers when we return.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BREAM: No sign that Congress will vote anytime soon on ending a partial government shutdown. Reopening the government will likely fall to the new congress, 116th, which starts next Thursday at noon. So, what exactly did the 115th Congress actually managed to get done? Back by popular demand, Fox News Senior Capitol Hill Producer Chad Pergram is here to break it down by the numbers. Chad?

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

CHAD PERGRAM, FOX NEWS SENIOR CAPITOL HILL PRODUCER: Shannon, 2018 marks the end of one of those rare times Republicans control the House and Senate. So, it's a good time to take stock of what the GOP did and didn't do. Take the long the longtime GOP promise to repeal and replace Obamacare. After one failed attempt, House Republicans finely muscled through their own health care measure that then died in the United States Senate. Republicans re-engineered to the nation's tax system for the first time in three decades.

GDP topped four percent in the second quarter of 2018 for the first time in four years. Yearly, economic average growth is now on track to hit three percent for the first time in 13 years. Nevertheless, political observers blame the tax law for Republicans losing house seats in New York, New Jersey and California. Residents could no longer deduct high local taxes from their federal tax bill. Congress never addressed an infrastructure bill. And there were a failed house bills to fund the border wall and provide pathways to citizenship for some DACA recipients. The president had this message for those Republicans during a press conference in late June.

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: And I think that's going to be a great election point for us. So, I told them two hours ago, I said, you're going to do what you want. And ultimately, we'll come to something, and perhaps, it will be after the election, maybe it will be before. But as of this moment, Democrats are not going to vote for anything because they really are resisting or obstructing. OK? Thank you very much.

PERGRAM: There were bipartisan successes. Democrats in the House and Senate finally got together on a long-awaited reform to the nation's criminal justice system. The law eliminates mandatory sentences, give inmates better training to reenter society ready to work. Lawmakers approved a major bill addressing the nation's opioid crisis. And even though part of the government is now closed, the Senate moved at its fastest clip in decades on annual spending bills. That's why this is a partial government shutdown. Congress worked out the details on five of the 12 appropriations bills months ago. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell often declared that the Senate is in the personnel business.

The Senate confirmed two Supreme Court nominees, including the knockdown, drag out fight over Brett Kavanaugh, also 32 circuit court judges and 51 district court judges. We all learned in fifth grade that Congress is designed to pass law -- quite the opposite. The founders created Congress to stop law. Consider this: lawmakers introduced 13,549 bills this Congress, 338 became law, that's 0.02 percent. 329 bills became law in the last Congress. And one bill, not destined to become a law this Congress legislation, to fund the approximate quarter of the government now held in limbo during the spending fight on a border wall. Shannon?

(END VIDEOTAPE)

BREAM: All right, Chad Pergram, thank you very much. We'll see you what 2019 brings. When it comes to cybersecurity, a year in review might highlight the billions of people affected by data breaches or even question over bias and social media content. And as Correspondent Gillian Turner reports, some in Congress are hoping 2019 might bring more oversight and online security.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

GILLIAN TURNER, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Members of Congress are using the partial government shutdown is an opportunity to sharpen their knives as they gear up for two big cyber battles in the new year. First up, regulating big tech. Both sides of the aisle have their sights set on the big three social media companies: Facebook, Twitter, and Google owned YouTube.

REP. TED POE (R), TEXAS: We are playing second fiddle to the Europeans. They protect the privacy of their folks more than we do.

SEN. AMY KLOBUCHAR (D), MINNESOTA: We have to put some rules of the road in place. They can't just say, hey, trust us, we got your back.

TURNER: But not everyone wants the same thing. Democrats want social media companies to get rid of fake news faster than they did in 2016 to avoid foreign election interference. Republicans want to hold the big three accountable for anti-conservative bias. One thing they can agree on: both parties want new legislation on the book before the 2020 campaign season kicks off.

Another issue, most Americans probably haven't heard too much about: data encryption. Republicans want legislation that forces tech companies like Apple to decrypt data when national security is at stake. They're taking cues from Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein, he's been keeping this issue in the spotlight, recently rebuking tech companies that refuse to decrypt their data for investigators.

"Companies are in the business of generating profit. I don't blame them for failing to consider law enforcement and public safety concerns but it's important to understand that what's good for a technology company isn't necessarily good for America." Democrats are focused on protecting Americans privacy. They worry if investigators can access any encrypted data they want, it will lead to abuses in the future.

2018 was a tough year for social media platforms and their users. Breaches of Facebook, Twitter, and Google alone resulted in 619 million user accounts compromised -- and that's a conservative estimate. Here's hoping 2019 is more secure. Shannon?

(END VIDEOTAPE)

BREAM: Sounds good, Gillian Turner, thank you very much. New laws for the new year, that's where we're headed in tonight's "REAL NEWS ROUNDUP." Starting January 1st, Washington State will begin imposing fines on people who try to pass off ordinary pets as service animals. Maximum penalty, $250. Meanwhile in California, judges will be able to decide who gets custody of a pet during a divorce proceeding. Judges will take into account who takes care of the pet and feeds them.

Tough gun control measures will go on the books in Illinois this year, they include a 72-hour waiting period on all gun purchases. Another new law will allow family members or police to ask a judge to temporally remove guns from someone they think is a threat to themselves or others.

In Tennessee, women will soon be required to get an ultrasound before getting an abortion. The doctor performing the ultrasound must also let the woman know the results of the test, namely whether or not a heartbeat is detected. Doctors will also be required to put that information into the patient's medical records.

President Trump's decision to pull out of Syria still being questioned by members of both parties. But the president now has an unlikely ally -- a former high-ranking Obama official. That story is next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BREAM: Troubling sign today for President Trump's withdrawal from Syria. It may have left an opening for Syria's president to regain some territory. But as Lucas Tomlinson reports, the Trump administration's new plan has support from a former senior Obama official.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

LUCAS TOMLINSON, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Syrian forces move to the outskirts of a Kurdish-held city captured from ISIS, putting hundreds of American troops in potential danger. Syrian President Bashar al-Assad's forces closed in ten days after President Trump ordered the full withdrawal of U.S. forces from the country. But the Kurds say, they welcome the Syrian troops in Manbij as protection against a potential Turkish invasion after their U.S. allies leave. Turkey's president says, he wants the Kurdish fighters out of the city immediately.

RECEP TAYYIP ERDOGAN, PRESIDENT OF TURKEY (through translator): Our entire aim is to make terror organizations leave the area. If terror organizations leave, then there is no work left for us anyway. Our communications and relationships with both the United States with President Trump, whom I spoke to recently, and Russia, continues healthily.

TOMLINSON: President Trump made the decision to pull out of Syria following a call with his Turkish counterpart earlier this month. The former U.S. ambassador to Syria under the Obama administration supports President Trump's decision to pull out: "Holding Northeastern Syria would not have been enabled Washington to leverage any important concessions from Damascus, Tehran or Moscow. Only Syrians, not U.S. troops and stabilization teams, can reverse that. We would do well to be humbler about our abilities, especially in the face of sustained, widespread regional hostility."

Seven years after the start of Syria civil war, President Assad no longer feels isolated. The Gulf States are long opposed to his rule are coming back to Damascus. Bahrain announced Friday it will reopen its embassy in Syria, one day after the United Arab Emirates did the same. U.S. officials tell me, there's no immediate plans to withdraw any American troops from Manbij, Syria. The complete withdrawal from a country could take months. Shannon?

BREAM: Lucas Tomlinson at the Pentagon, thank you. Impassioned pleas for 32 migrants who remained stranded in the Mediterranean, that leads tonight's "WHERE IN THE WORLD." The German nonprofit sea-watch making an impassioned appeal to E.U. states after no European nation agreed to take in 32 migrants who've been stranded at sea for the past week. The group rescued the migrants mainly from Nigeria, Libya, and Ivory Coast, December 22nd, just 24 hours after another group rescued more than 300 migrants who were eventually taken in by Spain.

Egyptian officials say a roadside bomb hit a tourist bus near the Giza pyramid, killing at least three people and wounding ten others. The countries battled Islamic militants for years but this is the first attack to target foreign tourists in nearly two years.

And Cuban officials are preparing to roll out fresh austerity measures as the cash-strapped nation continues to experience the weak economic growth, following export revenue and rising debt. Cuba's economy has averaged a one percent annual growth over the past three years. Foreign trade has also fallen by about 25 percent during that same period.

All right, does buying a ticket to a sporting event give you the right to cuss out the players? Well, one fan says, security roughed him up when he used foul language and he is now taking them to court. Our legal eagles, Marjorie and David are standing by to present their cases. You are the jury. "NIGHT COURT" is next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BREAM: It is time now for "NIGHT COURT." Another rocket docket, we're going to try to get through two cases here. First up, a Guatemalan family suing Universal theme park in Orlando. They say the park needs more bilingual signs because the family's 38-year-old father died of a heart attack two years ago after ridding to the skull island attraction. The family says a sign in English warning that it's a ride through Kingkong's natural habitat and people with heart condition shouldn't risk it. They said, well, there wasn't a sign in Spanish.

Now, the other case, New York Giants fans suing in a San Jose, California court for the right to curse at players and flip them off. These fans say their First Amendment rights were violated last year by police officers and security there after they flipped off Giants players and told them they "blanking suck" -- that's a quote. These are Giants fans, they were angry that their team was losing. So, tonight's legal eagles to weigh in and remember you're the jury: Marjorie Mesidor and David Bruno, thank you both for joining us tonight.

DAVID BRUNO, FORMER PROSECUTOR: Hello, Shannon.

MARJORIE MESIDOR, PARTNER, PHILLIPS & ASSOCIATES PLLC: Thank you for having us.

BREAM: OK, because we just showed a little video there. Let's start with the Giants case. They were at the game, they were yelling at their own players because they were so mad that they were losing this game. The police say that they were warned, they need to calm down, quit cursing at the players, without language, the flipping them off and it didn't work. They eventually ended up getting arrested. Let's get into a little bit of this.

A report afterwards, "The Captain Wahid Kazem of the Santa Clara Police Department saying this, that Patrick Flynn -- one of the plaintiffs in the case -- was belligerent, intoxicated and clearly violating the stadium's code of conduct. Kazem said that Patrick Flynn and Kyle Flynn, his brother, had been warned about their behavior, they were being ejected from the stadium when Kazem said they became uncooperative and physically resistant. The officers refused to leave their seats." Marjorie, that's the one side of the story. How do you respond?

MESIDOR: Well, when it -- when we're talking about issues of drunkenness and disorderly conduct and the like, that, in and of itself, there's no first amendment violation they are. But if we're just talking about the speech, whether or not they had a right to flip off to the players, et cetera, essentially, the First Amendment says that all speech, all those that don't fall into a particular exception, is essentially protected.

They interfered with that speech with the arrest, and essentially you have to then look at whether or not the limitation of that speech was justified by the fact that they want a safe environment. I don't think they're going to be able to show that it fell into one of the five exceptions of speech that is excluded from freedom of speech. It's not inciting a riot, it's not criminal, it's not criminal speech, it's not obscenity in terms of the way that the law looks at obscenity. It's not pornography or any one of those things. So, I think that they have a decent case here to say that there's a First Amendment violation.

BREAM: OK, part of their complaint says this, "The force used against the plaintiffs was excessive, unreasonable, without cause and with deliberate indifference to their health and safety." You saw at one point, one of the guys flips over one of the railings there. Plaintiffs suffered bodily injury, physical pain, emotional distress and deprivation of their constitutional rights. David, you know, in going through this pleading -- they also talked about the fact that one of the guys was taken into this holding area, he was put into a body wrap for 30 to 40 minutes, completely immobilizing him. I mean, this think really ratcheted up quickly it sounds like.

BRUNO: I think they have better claims about the injuries and the way that they are treated by the police than the First Amendment. Just getting back to the First Amendment briefly, this is a private place, it's a private stadium and the officer in that stadium used the word's code of conduct. Code of conduct prevents these people from acting unruly. So, security can detain, they could take them out, they could ask you to leave, they are allowed to do that.

On the injuries, while police have to act reasonable, and I'm sure the defense of the police officers is going to be -- well, they were resisting. That's what they were initially charged with. When somebody is resisting, it's not a good scene, does not look good, I've seen it on video. I did not see this one particularly but that is going to be the perspective and the defense from the police.

BREAM: OK. I get a little crazy at college football games myself, never arrested, though -- just for the record. OK, to this other case now at the theme park, I want to work through this. The family attorney suing Universal says, "It's not a crazy request that you would have signs in different languages, it's actually quite basic in this day age." They said, "You're asking for international travelers, this is a mecca for tourism -- talking about Central Florida -- this is a very basic thing that should be thought up for the safety of patrons." David?

BRUNO: Yes, I disagree that they legally have to do it. Is it a good idea? Yes, I think it's a good idea. But to file a lawsuit and claim that this Orlando theme park was negligent in not posting a Spanish sign, I disagree. The fact of the matter is, 72 million visitors came to the Orlando theme parks outside of the United States and they're from all different languages. It's not just a Spanish. In addition, they had an English warning and there were also pictures that went with that. It's not just Spanish. Pictures probably were enough to give this guy notice. But you know what, he was going on the right anyway.

BREAM: Marjorie, I want to give the final word here on this case.

MESIDOR: Well, for me, it's simply an issue of whether or not they had a duty of care. What is a point of having a sign if everyone who is attending this theme park can't read it or interact with it? The fact of the matter is, is that there are 41 million Spanish speakers in the United States, there's over a million who come in from outside countries, mostly predominantly Spanish-speaking countries. It's not a one-off that a place like Universal Studios or a theme park like this one would have a Spanish sign in Spanish for these kinds of warnings, especially if it's a health risk. Safety is a safety issue for everyone, not just for the English speakers and for -- in addressing this issue that they really should have it in both languages.

BREAM: All right. Marjorie and David, thank you for making your arguments. We appreciate your time tonight. We put it to the jury. Let us know what you think @FoxNewsNight or @ShannonBream, you'll weigh in. Thanks, guys.

MESIDOR: Thank you.

BREAM: And tonight, we end on a very somber note. We would like to pay tribute and say farewell to Bre Payton, she'd been a guest on our program, she was a very close friend with our lead writer who is obviously, like so many other people today, devastated by the news that this beautiful 26- year-old woman, brilliant and smart, suddenly passed away today in San Diego.

Bre was a writer for The Federalist news site. Her family, friends, and colleagues are all shocked at her death. We're told possibly H1N1 flu or meningitis was involved. A little bit early at this point, but our prayers are with her and her friends and family. They've set up a scholarship fund that will go towards those supporting young, rising Christian leaders. We remember Bre tonight.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MEDIA CONVENTION Berlin (#MCB19) und re:publica (#rp19) stellen ihr diesjaehriges Programm vor, das erneut ueber 400 Sessions und Keynotes umfasst. Seit sechs Jahren finden beide Veranstaltungen gemeinsam in der STATION Berlin statt und bieten einen einzigartigen Einblick in die Bereiche Netzkultur, digitale Technologien, Medienpolitik und neue Geschaeftsmodelle. Vom 6. bis 8. Mai 2019 treffen sich erneut die internationale digitale Szene, Vertreter*innen von Medienunternehmen, Netzpolitiker*innen und alle, die in Fragen der Medien- und Netzpolitik, Medienwirtschaft und Medientrends auf dem neuesten Stand sein, sich inspirieren lassen und austauschen moechten. Auf drei Buehnen, in ueber 60 Sessions praesentiert die #MCB19 ein vielfaeltiges, aktuelles Programm und weist mit dem diesjaehrigen Thema "Playing for Keeps: Jetzt wird's ernst!" auf die enormen wirtschaftlichen, regulatorischen und gesellschaftlichen Veraenderungen hin, die die Digitalisierung mit sich bringt.

Zum Auftakt der MCB19 wird der Regierende Buergermeister von Berlin, Michael Mueller, ein Grusswort sprechen. In der anschliessenden Eroeffnungs-Keynote spricht Malu Dreyer, Ministerpraesidentin und Vorsitzende der Rundfunkkommission der Laender, ueber die Gestaltung der digitalen Gesellschaft, Werte und Demokratie im digitalen Zeitalter, Medienvielfalt und den Umgang mit marktstarken digitalen Plattformen.

Auch im Eroeffnungs-Panel "Point of no Return - Going All In with Digital" geht es um den digitalen Paradigmenwechsel und die Integration von digitalen Geschaeftsfeldern als Bestandteil von Unternehmensstrategien. Alina Fichter (Newsguard) spricht mit Nadine Bilke (ZDFneo), Dr. Holger Ensslin (Sky Deutschland), Dan Maag (PANTALEON Films, PANTAFLIX) und Eun-Kyung Park (ProSiebenSat.1 Media SE) darueber, wie es gelingen kann, ein komplettes Unternehmen auf Digital umzustellen.

Wie in einer Post-Rundfunk-Aera Auffindbarkeit, Meinungsvielfalt und ein demokratischer Diskurs gesichert werden koennen, diskutiert Moderator Joachim Huber (Tagesspiegel) mit Staatssekretaer Thomas Kralinski (Bevollmaechtigter des Landes Brandenburg beim Bund), Patricia Schlesinger (Rundfunk Berlin-Brandenburg), Tobias Schmid (Landesanstalt fuer Medien NRW), Eva Flecken (Sky Deutschland) und Marie-Teresa Weber (Facebook Germany) in der Session "Ende einer Aera. Wenn aus Rundfunk Medien werden". Jan Penfrat (European Digital Rights) leitet das Panel mit seiner Keynote ueber neue EU-Richtlinien fuer Plattformen und Intermediaere ein.

Hinter die Kulissen von High-End-Serienproduktionen koennen die Besucher*innen der MCB in diesem Jahr erneut bei der Session "TV Made in Germany - Meet the Team" blicken. Mit dabei ist das Team der neuen VOX-Eigenproduktion "Das Wichtigste im Leben", vertreten durch die Hauptdarsteller*innen Juergen Vogel und Bettina Lamprecht, Hauke Bartel (VOX), Richard Kropf (Drehbuch), Laura Lackmann (Regie) und Lasse Scharpen (Bantry Bay). Ausserdem begruesst die MCB Hauptdarstellerin Mai Duong Kieu, Lisa Blumenberg (Letterbox Filmproduktion), Caroline von Senden (ZDF Redaktion Fernsehspiel I) und Christian Zuebert (Regie) vom Team "Bad Banks" sowie das Team von "Die Neue Zeit" mit den Hauptdarstellerin Anna Maria Muehe, Lars Kraume (Buch & Regie) und Thomas Kufus (Produzent).

Nutzerdaten als Wettbewerbsvorteil: Bundeskartellamtspraesident Andreas Mundt spricht im Panel "Big Tech im Check. Wettbewerb um Daten und Chancengleichheit im Netz" ueber das Facebook-Verfahren und Daten als Marktmacht-Faktor. Mit Justus Haucap (Institute for Competition Economics), Dennis Kaben (Google Germany), Holger Ensslin (Sky Deutschland), Katharina de la Durantaye (Europa-Universitaet Viadrina) und Journalistin und Moderatorin Vera Linss geht es im Anschluss um Chancengleichheit und einen fairen Wettbewerb um Nutzerdaten.

Ein Fokus der diesjaehrigen MCB liegt auf dem Thema Podcast. In der zweiteiligen Session "The Golden Age of Podcasting" spricht Tobias Bauckhage (Creators Media, Los Angeles) zunaechst mit Joel Lovell (Pineapple Media) ueber die Historie des aktuellen Podcast-Booms in den USA. In einer zweiten Session diskutiert er mit Nick Quah (Hot Pod Media, New York) ueber die wirtschaftliche Seite des derzeitigen Erfolgs von Podcasts in den Vereinigten Staaten.

Im Panel "Medien, Manipulation und Microtargeting. Wie Social Media den Wahlkampf mit politischer Werbung dominiert" praesentiert Simon Hegelich (Technische Universitaet Muenchen) neben neuen Studienergebnissen zum Thema "Microtargeting in Deutschland und Europa" auch ein Online-Tool, das Einblicke in Wahlkampfaktivitaeten auf Facebook, Twitter & Co. ermoeglicht. Im Anschluss diskutiert er mit Tabea Wilke (botswatch Technologies), Semjon Rens (Facebook Germany), Manon Metz (DIRK METZ Kommunikation), mabb-Direktorin Anja Zimmer und Journalist und Moderator Daniel Fiene darueber, wie politische Werbung in den sozialen Netzwerken umgesetzt wird und welche Herausforderungen sich fuer die Regulierung ergeben.

Wie man gute VR-Experiences entwickelt und welche Geschichten wirklich geeignet sind fuer immersives Storytelling stellen Sven Bliedung (Volucap), Sebastian Sylwan (Felix&Paul Studios) und Karim Ben Khelifa (The Enemy) in der Session "VR & AR: The Art of Immersive Storytelling" vor.

"The new abnormal: Hate, Fakes, Mobbing. Wie machen wir das Netz zu einem besseren Ort?" - Diese Frage stellt Moderatorin Nadine Kreutzer den Diskussionsteilnehmer*innen Alexandra Borchardt (University of Oxford), Teresa Buecker (Edition F), Markus Heidmeier (Kooperative Berlin) und Marco Holtz (Medienanstalt Berlin-Brandenburg), der in diesem Zusammenhang auch das Projekt "Verfolgen statt nur Loeschen" vorstellt.

Game Engines koennen mehr als Spiele: Schon laengst werden sie in Industrie und Medienwirtschaft auch ausserhalb des klassischen Gamings eingesetzt. Pascal Tonecker (Cryengine Enterprise Solutions), Andreas Suika (Unreal Engine Evangelist, Epic Games) und Thomas Bedenk (Exozet) stellen sich der Frage "What's in a Game? Spiel-Engines als Motor fuer Film, XR und Industrie".

Wie muessen humanistische Plattformen aussehen, bei denen der Mensch im Mittelpunkt steht? Das beleuchtet Philosoph und Sozialwissenschaftler Joe Edelman in seiner Keynote zum Panel "Designing better platforms. Was nachhaltige, humanistische digitale Plattformen auszeichnet". Moderator Daniel Budiman diskutiert anschliessend mit Politikwissenschaftlerin Ingrid Schneider (Universitaet Hamburg), Philipp Otto (iRights.Lab) und Gesche Joost (Universitaet der Kuenste Berlin) ueber Werte und Prinzipien einer neuen Art von Plattform.

Wie weit muessen Sender und Produzenten im "War for Talents" gehen? Die Frage danach, welche Arbeitsbedingungen Nachwuchstalente hinter der Kamera vorfinden sollten, um attraktiven, sinnvollen und diversen Content entwickeln und herstellen zu koennen, beleuchten Christian Rohde (UFA Fiction GmbH) und Grischa Boehmer (EPI, Winterclass - Serial Writing And Producing), Christine Troestrum (Berlinale Talents) und Ben Gibson (dffb Serial Eyes und Next Wave) in der Session "Goldene Zeiten - aber wo ist der Nachwuchs?".

Die MCB19 wird vom Medienboard Berlin-Brandenburg und von der Medienanstalt Berlin-Brandenburg veranstaltet.

    Medienboard-Geschaeftsfuehrer Helge Juergens erklaert:

"Bei der Digitalisierung geht es nicht mehr um ein Zusatzgeschaeft. Digitale Geschaeftsmodelle werden immer mehr zum Kerngeschaeft der klassischen Medienunternehmen, ob am Streaming-, Film- und TV-Markt oder bei den grossen Social-Media- und Gaming-Plattformen. Auf der MCB19 diskutieren wir mit den Protagonisten*innen der Branche, wie hoch deren Einsaetze sein muessen, um am Markt bestehen zu koennen."

"Es wird ernst im Kampf um Medienvielfalt", so mabb-Direktorin Anja Zimmer. "Auf der MCB19 diskutieren wir darueber, wie wir weiter in einer vielfaeltigen, demokratischen Gesellschaft leben koennen. Dafuer braucht es zum Beispiel wirksame Mittel, um die Meinungsfreiheit zu schuetzen und gegen Hassbotschaften vorzugehen. Es bedarf regulatorischer Mechanismen, um diskriminierungsfreien Zugang und Auffindbarkeit von journalistischen Inhalten zu sichern. Und schliesslich brauchen wir Foerderung fuer lokale Medieninhalte und Journalisten, die lokale Nachrichten in laendlichen Raeumen veroeffentlichen."

Ueber die MEDIA CONVENTION (MCB)

Die MEDIA CONVENTION Berlin (MCB) ist einer der fuehrenden Medienkongresse in Europa. Das Medienboard Berlin-Brandenburg (MBB) und die Medienanstalt Berlin-Brandenburg (mabb) veranstalten die MCB in Kooperation mit der re:publica und im Auftrag der Laender Berlin und Brandenburg. Aktuelle Fragen zu Medien- und Netzpolitik, Markttrends und Entwicklungen der digitalen Mediengesellschaft werden in Keynotes, Fireside-Chats und auf Panels diskutiert sowie in Workshops und Best-practice-Praesentationen hinterfragt und auf ihre Anwendbarkeit geprueft. Darueber hinaus praesentieren zukunftsweisende Akteure der digitalen Szene aus der Hauptstadtregion ihre Ideen und Entwicklungen - von Medieninnovationsprojekten bis hin zu neuen Geschaeftsmodellen.
