urn:contentItem:5N65-B9X1-DXH2-60K1-00000-00Alliance Data Systems Corp at KBW Cards, Payments & Financial Technology Symposium - Final2017-02-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:08:51ZLexisNexis022717a8224289.789Alliance Data Systems Corp at KBW Cards, Payments & Financial Technology Symposium - Final

Corporate Participants

* Ed Heffernan

Alliance Data Systems Corporation - President & CEO

Conference Call Participants

* Sanjay Sakhrani

Keefe, Bruyette & Woods - Analyst

Presentation

SANJAY SAKHRANI, ANALYST, KEEFE, BRUYETTE & WOODS: Our next speaker is Ed Heffernan, CEO and President at Alliance Data Systems. Obviously, the Company combines digital marketing with loyalty and private label. While there is obviously a number of moving pieces across all of their businesses, clearly, the Company is set up for a very strong finish to the year and into next year. So please join me in welcoming Ed Heffernan. Thank you, Ed, for participating again.

I want to start off with my seven years experience of ADS. I feel like there has been no shortage of excitement and controversy in the name. Historically, it centered around one segment, maybe two. Last year, it plagued all of your businesses, some not within your control, so to speak, but I think it has left investors wondering whether it's an indication of the pieces not fitting together and perhaps you could just talk about why you continue to believe the pieces fit together and what's going to prove that thesis out.

ED HEFFERNAN, PRESIDENT & CEO, ALLIANCE DATA SYSTEMS CORPORATION: Sure. Again, with Alliance, it is a business that is very different. If you start with -- I know this is a heavy reliance on financial services, but we are not a bank. It's a non-bank holdco that allows us to have both a financial institution that is regulated, as well as a number of other assets that a traditional bank can't own like all the data-driven and analytical stuff that we do.

And so it comes back to the founding of the Company way back when when we started it back in the late 1990s. The whole thesis was that there should be a way to take data that is flying around all these networks and transaction processors and use that information to gain insight into the consumer, which will then allow you to market in a very precise fashion to those consumers.

And what we did is we essentially said, all right, our job is to build a bunch of platforms and they are going to appeal to different verticals. And so in areas such as specialty apparel, specialty retail, so apparel, jewelry, high-end home furnishings, things like that, the private label card, so it's a loyalty platform with liquidity attached to it, is very appealing.

If you move into the auto space or financial services and other verticals, they might not want that piece and they just want the loyalty platform, so we will be the Citibank Thank You platform; we will build Hilton Honors and the Walgreens. Those are huge loyalty programs.

In other parts of the world, like in Canada, it was deemed more appropriate to have all the big verticals come together and build a coalition loyalty program. So the bottom line of the Company is that we have a bunch of collection devices, which are platforms.

Some of it offers up a liquidity component, which is the credit card. Some of it is just the loyalty component. Some of it is just a coalition loyalty, but the whole point is to extract the data and information and use that to do targeted marketing and that's where it all fits together and it's more challenging when we describe it to investors and Wall Street because people tend to be a bit more focused on I'm in financial services, or I'm in marketing, or I'm in e-commerce or something like that.

We cut across it, so it does make sense from the viewpoint of build platforms to collect information, use the information to market to the customers' clients. That's what we do.

SANJAY SAKHRANI: I appreciate that. From your discussions with investors, what do you think they need to see to regain confidence in the story and get the stock back to historical valuation levels?

ED HEFFERNAN: Yes, I think for those of you who know me, I'm certainly not shy about being fairly blunt. I think we've gone through different cycles in all the years that I've been there and sometimes there are macro issues. Sometimes there are legal issues or regulatory issues. Sometimes there are client issues that all can knock you off course. And I think we've certainly had our share of those over the past couple of years and our goal is to basically use this year as the year where we don't have any of those little surprises. We think we have essentially tripped over every single one that is out there and we've set up the Company at this point where it's no longer going to be a macro issue or a regulatory issue. We either execute or we don't.

We have three businesses. All three businesses have very specific targets and goals that must be met for this year and those are all internal. There are no real external things that we are worried about and as a result, if the three businesses execute, what you'll see is you will move to a strong double-digit growth as we enter Q3, Q4 and then the acceleration for 2018, you are looking at essentially doubling the growth rate of the Company for 2018, what we call our slingshot effect.

SANJAY SAKHRANI: I think you have been clear in that you think the stock is undervalued given the fundamentals you've just outlined. You have mentioned you are going to remain aggressive with the share buyback. You have a $500 million authorization. How should we think about the remaining uses of free cash flow?

ED HEFFERNAN: Sure. If you look at our Company and if you look at the card business, if we grow the card business $2.5 billion, $3 billion a year in the portfolio, then you are going to need to set aside capital equal to roughly 15% of that growth. So that's the first use of capital.

The next piece would be, at least in today's environment, we have allocated a fair amount to share buybacks to the tune of I think we did about $800 million last year. Our first leg up this year is $500 million and that has taken precedence.

The past couple years, we instituted a dividend at the end of last year, which seemed to be something that folks were looking for. But, at the end of the day, we are a growth company and if you looked at our track record over the last 10 years, we've grown both top line and earnings double digit for the last 15 years.

So I would like to get back to enhancing the organic growth rate, which is probably in the high single digits with a little bit of M&A. Once we get out of this funk here and get moving and grooving in the back half, you look at a combo of capital for growth in the card business in terms of the portfolio. You will have capital for stock repurchases and you will have capital for very modest M&A. If I could do a third, a third, a third, that would be great given our operating cash flow is well north of $1 billion.

SANJAY SAKHRANI: And when we think about M&A, what are you looking towards, which segments?

ED HEFFERNAN: We very much like the business in brand loyalty, which is based out of the Netherlands, which does loyalty programs for grocers. That's been growing steadily at I'd say 10% a year. We think that can expand even faster, so we would look for something there.

We would also look to enhance our digital and data capabilities at both BrandLoyalty and our business in Canada and at Epsilon. And there's nothing big hanging out there.

SANJAY SAKHRANI: And would it be in the US or broad -- it could be broader?

ED HEFFERNAN: It could be either.

SANJAY SAKHRANI: Got it. Maybe shifting gears to private label first since it's a card conference. For 2017, there was some moderation in receivables growth expected, 15% versus the 20% in 2016. You've talked about same-store sales comps being weaker. Maybe you could just talk about the trajectory of that growth going forward given this backdrop because I think it caught some people by surprise.

ED HEFFERNAN: Yes. I don't think it's to anyone's surprise as to how soft the holiday season was for your more traditional retailers and that has a direct impact on us. So typically, retailers would grow let's say 3% comps year-over-year and the way our business is set up, our goal is, or our whole mousetrap is our ability to get deeper and deeper into the consumer's mindset and increase their spend. And so if the retailer did 3%, our growth rate from that retailer could be more like 8%.

So that's called tender share gain and that is essentially after she has purchased one item, our ability to know about that item down to the SKU level and then go back and reach her and convince her that the shoes and the belt and everything else would be an ideal complement to the initial purchase has been very successful.

So our goal is our first 8 points of growth traditionally came out of that core business. That core business is now running at minus 1%, minus 2% from holiday and that essentially means that we will still add 5 points onto that, but you go from minus 2% to plus 3%, not plus 3% to plus 8%. So our whole core has shifted down by about 5 points and as a result, we need to figure out, okay, should we figure out a way to board another -- it would take us probably another three new clients a year to make up that difference and the answer right now is, yes, we think that offsetting that has been this massive secular trend that has moved the dollars and marketing budgets away from TV and newspaper and mail inserts and circulars and all that other stuff and has shifted it over to this data-driven targeted marketing.

So you have a negative on comps, but you have a positive on the secular trend. The net result is we are going to be able to hold serve, so to speak and the growth rate of the file between 15% and 20% a year seems very sustainable for the next several years based on the pipeline. We've got about 350 potential clients that we think fit our sandbox. We have 155 of them today, so we are about halfway through and the vast bulk of the majority don't have a program. It's not like they are with someone else. They just allocated their dollars traditionally to other areas of marketing and now they are all shifting back over to compete with some of the pure online players.

SANJAY SAKHRANI: You alluded to this before, but a lot of the pressure that we are seeing in retail is in apparel and at malls. Could you just talk about why you might not necessarily be as concerned, why you think you can still post double-digit growth in that backdrop outside of just the -- spooling new relationships?

ED HEFFERNAN: Sure. I think there are areas that are growing quite well. So the specialty beauty places are doing quite well. Fast fashion is doing quite well and then the pure e-commerce players are doing quite well.

So what you are seeing is you are almost looking like at a fragmentation of the department store. So for those of you who have been in department stores, there are sometimes three or four different specialty brands that sell their products within the overall department store and what they're doing is they are breaking away and they are creating their own e-commerce sites. And so this fragmentation is taking sales away from your more traditional players and that is where we need to step in and say, hey, our ability to board and to spool up these smaller specialty pure play type retailers, that's going to be a key piece of our focus going forward.

The second thing would be on the digital side and of course, everyone talks all digital all the time, but we view it as a nice complement to the bricks. And so you are going to hear more and more about what we call bricks and mobile. That is going to be the new thing that you are going to hear about. No one shops anymore without first being on their mobile device looking at pricing and that's what's causing all the compression in the margins. But don't forget, 85% of sales are still done at the physical store itself and 15% is online.

For us, almost 40% of our sales are online, which essentially means that we are taking the information from the store purchase, looking at it, figuring out how do we get the next incremental purchase out of that customer and using that intel to go out and reach her and provide her with an offer that she can get excited about and that will drive these incremental sales over and over and over again and that's how we build up our tender share that frankly at some of our clients we are at 50% or 60% of sales are flowing through our product and overall for the Company, we are only at 30%.

So there's quite a ways to go with tender share and the more focused on data and digital and identifying who she is, what she bought down to the SKU level is only to our benefit.

SANJAY SAKHRANI: I'm glad you knocked out my tender share question.

ED HEFFERNAN: I tried.

SANJAY SAKHRANI: Appreciate it. So one more on just the pipeline and I guess the sandbox. I think that you have talked historically about the numbers of opportunities there are and how big you are today. Could you just refresh us on that and maybe just talk about your comfort in expanding the pot?

ED HEFFERNAN: Yes. Look, at the end of the day, you've got -- the card market, as people know, is primarily Visa/MasterCard. It's massive portfolios with huge clients. That's not us. We tend to be very focused. Our average portfolio size is about $60 million or $70 million. Our typical customer or client's customer is -- 93% are female and they typically have this as not their primary card. They use one of the big Visa/MasterCard products or a co-brand product and that's fine with us. We want this to be her favorite brand and view it as a loyalty program.

So you have $500 balances and $800 credit lines that are just a fraction of the big co-brands and that's fine with us. Most of the other, I think, folks that you are going to hear are talking about these multi-billion dollar files and everything else. We are not competitive frankly in those areas. We are not competitive in co-brand. We are not really competitive with a general-purpose bankcard and the reason for that is pretty straightforward, which is our whole model is based upon someone who has multiple transactions, 8 to 10 trips a year whether it's to the mall or to the computer and using that information to drive very targeted sales.

And we find that those are usually areas where you have retailers with very, very strong brand presence and view their brand as everything and so they are willing to spend a lot to build up these brands and for us, that's our specialty, that's what we are good at. Everything is done in house from the underwriting, to the network and processing, the closed loop is within our house. The customer care is US-based and all the data and marketing is done in-house as well.

So everyone must sign up for all of this and for us to do that, we can't accept a return that you are seeing today on some of these co-brand deals of a couple of points, ROAs and stuff like that; that doesn't work for us. And so we go for smaller clients, have a very deep vertical relationship with those clients and as a result, we tend to have returns, ROEs that are 30% plus; ROAs in the 800 basis points, 700 basis points. It's just a very unique product and that's what we are focused on.

SANJAY SAKHRANI: And your competitors talk about doing more of that and I guess I was just wondering how you feel about the competition and their relative positioning compared to previous years.

ED HEFFERNAN: Yes, I think from a competitive perspective, what I have seen is, again, we have 20% of our book is co-brand, but 85% of that is an add-on to an existing private label relationship.

So I think the competitive set that outsources a lot of other functions, they are focused on big balances, big portfolios because they are big. To move the needle, you need big numbers. When you start getting into personalized service for a $70 million file, it's harder and harder for the real big banks to do that and as a result, we carved out our area.

Now everyone is going to talk about digital this and data that and that's fine, but our name is Alliance Data and of our 18,000 people, we probably have 12,000 of them that are focused on data in marketing as opposed to it's more of a nice to have, we want to grow that piece of the business. That is our business and the credit piece is merely a means to an end to get to the data.

So our whole heritage comes from the retailer side when the Company was formed in the late 1990s through some assets from The Limited and from JCPenney and so it's a very different sort of founding and growth from a traditional bank.

SANJAY SAKHRANI: So my final question on private label and I would be remiss not to talk about it is credit quality.

ED HEFFERNAN: Really?

SANJAY SAKHRANI: Obviously, you guys have gone on a limb and given us a projection of how you expect credit to trend over the course of the year. What gives you the confidence that you will execute against those goals?

ED HEFFERNAN: Yes, it's two things. The first thing we do is, again, with 155 clients, what we do is we will go portfolio by portfolio, vintage by vintage and do a bottoms-up approach across every single file and see how things are trending. We knew at the beginning of 2016 that this so-called normalization process, whereby loss rates which were abnormally low by historical standards, were beginning to normalize to a run rate more consistent with what we are used to.

A lot of that had to do with coming out of the Great Recession. All you had were these super high FICO or scored accounts that were acceptable and now people have repaired their credit and you're getting to a more normalized level.

What that effectively did last year and this year is it knocked 10 points of growth off of our growth rate. We will still grow double digit, that's against a headwind of 10 to 12 percentage points on your earnings per share from this normalization process when you are also growing so quickly.

So you've got those two big things. So the concept is gosh, when that finally stabilizes and normalizes, the math gets very simple. Your growth rate doubles. You eliminate 10 to 12 points of drag. It's that simple. It's just math. And so the question is when is that going to happen and so what you are going to see this year -- let me talk about losses and delinquencies.

From a loss rate perspective, you had a business that was growing 27% last year and at that growth rate, those were when the losses started to get generated and they are flowing through in the first half of this year and that's why the loss rate for the first half of the year will have a 6 handle or a 6 as the first digit and then by Q3, you are actually going to drop below 5.5 because that piece has been cleaned out of the system because you are going from a 27% growth rate to a 15%.

What that does is you have the denominator effect that causes those losses to seem higher than they normally would. That result is that flows through the system in the first half. Back half, Q3 will below 5.5 and by that point, we are basically at that, hey, we are normalizing out here.

What gives us the comfort that that normalization is going to happen? To us, it's all driven by delinquencies. The correlation between delinquencies are when an account gets behind on their and when the actual loss hits your P&L is 180 days. So you should be able to look out 180 days and figure out what your loss rate will be.

And so as we look at these delinquencies, you would see last year they were going up 50 basis points, 50 basis points, oh, and the loss rate went up 50, 60 basis points. This year, it looks like the same thing. They are beginning to go up 50, 60 basis points, something like that and then what we are saying is then it's going to start to narrow and that's called the wedge.

And so as we move into the middle of the year, what you are going to see are those delinquency rates getting closer and closer together so that by the fall they will actually touch. And when they touch, that means you fully normalized, which therefore means the losses that will flow out three to six months after that will be at the same rate as the prior year. That will cause your growth to accelerate by 10 or 12 percentage points. That's the slingshot.

So the question right now is, okay, we need to watch this wedge close as the year progresses and that's essentially there is nothing more we can do at that point is just put the numbers up and see that it closes. I will say that I think we are going to be pretty darn close to the wedge. I will say -- I do have to say that there's been a big delay in the tax refunds for -- help me out here -- with the childcare credit.

SANJAY SAKHRANI: There's just been an overall delay in getting people back their refund.

ED HEFFERNAN: Yes, there's like a 45-day delay so that delinquency levels, which normally would be relatively flat, will blip up about 20 basis points in February and then start dropping back down again. So it's transitory. It doesn't change the loss profile. It doesn't change where the wedge is going, but everyone should be aware that there's about $100 billion that the government delayed from early January to late February and these were usually used to cure delinquent accounts. That's going away starting the latter part of March.

We saw -- actually we heard last Wednesday -- you will hear this from other companies -- last Wednesday is when we started to see money in the system. So it looks like it was almost precisely a 40-day delay on that, but otherwise the wedge looks good. We will get to where we need to be and then have a slingshot into 2018.

SANJAY SAKHRANI: Okay. I'm going to shift gears to Epsilon because I think it's an equal, if not -- it's an equally important topic for this year. You have talked about accelerating revenue growth towards the back part of the year, turning around specifically from the technology platform's offering. Maybe you could just talk about what the execution risks are there because I think it's obviously a big part of the turnaround there.

ED HEFFERNAN: Sure. So Epsilon, which has a number of different data and digital products, probably 70%, 75% of Epsilon is currently growing at 6% or 7% and looks like that's in pretty good shape.

The area where we got tripped up on is our big tech platform business, again, the business that builds those massive loyalty programs like Hilton Honors and Citi Thank You and everything else. For as long as I could remember, that used to grow 8% a year year after year after year. Last year, it declined 5%. And that's what dragged down all of Epsilon.

And as we dug into it, what we found was that the market had shifted dramatically and we were off on two things -- price point and time to deliver. And specifically, we or the DNA of Epsilon with 8,000 engineers is to build the coolest thing out there. And for those of you who are engineers, you can't stop tinkering with anything until it's basically, hey, pencils down.

So that was the case at Epsilon and we built the fanciest things out there, these platforms with bells and whistles and they are still awesome and they cost a lot of money and they took 12 months to deliver. Well, what we found out from CMOs is, hey, 12 months, that ain't going to cut it anymore; I need it in three and I need it for 20% less because they are after my budget.

And that is not our DNA and we had a very difficult time adjusting to it to be quite honest. To get the price point fixed, we needed to, for the first time, open up a very significant office in India with engineers over there. We have about 1,000 people there now. We have our labor costs now in line where the price point is right. Now we essentially need to come up with a shrink-wrapped product that has maybe 80% of the functionality and can be delivered in three months and doesn't have all the bells and whistles and that's what we are working on right now.

And we expect -- we are already selling it into the marketplace. We expect deliveries to start in July and that's basically what we are doing to fix the issue. So if we go from minus 5% or 6% decline to just flat by the end of the year, that's when you'll see all of Epsilon then start growing at that 6% or 7% growth rate on a go-forward basis as we move into maybe plus 2% in 2018.

So they are not huge hurdles that we are trying to hit, but from a DNA perspective, from a cultural perspective, you are basically asking people to stop building the Ferrari and deliver to the market something that is less expensive and doesn't have all the bells and whistles that it used to have and that's what we are working through right now.

SANJAY SAKHRANI: So the execution risk for this year, is it that you are not able to sell it into the market, or is there a pipeline that helps the second half of the year?

ED HEFFERNAN: The pipeline actually looks pretty good. Our biggest question to CMOs had to do with is this something you really want to do in-house? Do you want a SaaS-based solution where you hire 100 analysts and run the thing in-house, or do you want us to do all of that and it's really just a question of price and delivery time. And the answer came back a little bit of both, so I think there's going to be markets where I think you are going to have a number of CMOs who want control of it and will have a SaaS-based solution in-house with 100 analysts and then there will be our solution where we will do everything and the CMO can sit there and run the business and sell cars or whatever they are supposed to sell.

SANJAY SAKHRANI: So you suspect that will continue to evolve within your own customer base as well?

ED HEFFERNAN: Yes.

SANJAY SAKHRANI: And so you are going to have to attract other people that use SaaS-based platforms as well?

ED HEFFERNAN: Yes, the good news is everyone is shifting all their money over to this stuff. Everyone out there -- you talk to any CMO, their marketing dollars are going dramatically faster towards this anything data-driven that can give insights into who their customer is, how do I get hold of a prospect, how do I reach them over all these different channels and that means that the overall sandbox is growing and all we want is our piece of the full-service offering and then you'll have the SaaS-based offering over here.

SANJAY SAKHRANI: I'm going to get one in on loyalty and then I'm going to go to the audience. So put together your questions, audience. Obviously, with loyalty, the no-expiry model is back into play. Some of it is beyond your control based on what happened legislatively there.

But I guess the key here is customer engagement going forward as you guys evolve the business model. How do you foresee that evolving? What are the risks that those customers don't engage as they did before?

ED HEFFERNAN: For those of you who missed the end of last year, it got pretty entertaining around Thanksgiving when the Parliament in Ontario decided to outlaw what we did for a living and that was essentially disallowed our ability to expire points after five years and therefore, we couldn't recognize those earnings.

So after that took place, we obviously needed to think about how do we retool this model to get back to a level of profitability where we were before and that's what we are doing right now. It's really not the most ideal way of going through the transition, but essentially what we are doing is this is a massive coalition program with two-thirds of Canadians enrolled in this program, so it's the national consumer coalition program for all of Canada and what we are doing is, for the first time, we are working with suppliers; we are working across the various reward categories to find ways whereby we can recapture that margin that was lost through the change in the law.

Said differently, we fully expect to be back to an EBITDA margin of 25%, 26% by Q3 of this year with the changes we are making to the model. That should be pretty straightforward.

The second thing is did we do damage to the brand with all the noise that was up there? And there was a lot of noise. If anyone is from Canada, it was quite a scene. And what we found fortunately from our sponsors, the people who are in the coalition is, everyone is standing pat. Everyone had to make some noise, but right now across the board they are basically saying get on with it. We've got businesses to run. Let's move past it. Let's get back in the game here and let's reengage and that's what we are doing.

So for the first half of this year, a lot of our efforts will be re-engaging with the collectors to make sure they know the value of the program, make sure that they feel like they are not getting stiffed, that this thing actually has true value and we are spending a lot of money to get that message across.

And so the proof of it will be probably as we move into really the back half of this year, the issuance level of these points or miles needs to return to plus 3%, plus 4% for us to know for certain that the engagement has worked.

SANJAY SAKHRANI: Cool. Audience, any questions?

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: So just in terms of -- on the private label side, I know you guys always have contingency plans around different scenarios, but if the wedge doesn't completely match or doesn't play out perfectly as you guys expect, what's the contingency plan for -- if Charles were here or your [son] -- are there other options you guys can do to try to get that wedge back in order? And I'm not saying I don't think it's going to happen, just wondering about contingency if possible.

ED HEFFERNAN: Yes, it's a fair question. You are basically questioning whether or not we are going to fully normalize our loss rate before the end of this year and as a result allow for that slingshot into 2018 and the question is what happens if it takes a little bit longer, what happens if you are not right? What does that mean?

I would say right now that everything seems to suggest that it is going to close very nicely as we start heading into the spring and then the summer and if it, for whatever reason, were off a bit, there are a number of things you can do. You can be more aggressive on the new client signings and so you start moving your growth rate back from 15% to more like 20%. If you do that, then, by definition, you are going to have -- you are not going to have that grow-over issue when you slow like we are this year. That would be one thing we would do.

If we are off a little bit and the earnings are coming in a little bit lighter, which I don't think they will, but you asked the question, fortunately, we have a lot of free cash flow. We would continue to be very aggressive from a buyback perspective until the wedge does close.

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: Okay, thanks.

SANJAY SAKHRANI: Other questions in the room? So I've got a question on the agency part of the business for Epsilon. Obviously, four to five years ago, the big push was to get the agency model or businesses to really drive the deals. When you look across the industry, the agency growth rates have been stronger than what you are seeing. Could you maybe just explain what's happening at Epsilon versus what we are seeing in the industry and whether or not you believe moving to that agency-heavy model has made sense?

ED HEFFERNAN: Yes. Actually, if you recall, in Q4, we actually saw growth return pretty nicely to agency, so the Epsilon agency business is growing 4% to 5% today. So I think we had a couple of speed bumps there in terms of some clients curtailing some of their spend, but the agency piece is running 4% or 5%, which is about what we want it.

The one piece of agency that continues to suffer would be the old value-click business that provided inventory to the big Madison Avenue agencies. That's become more of a commodity. It's 4% of overall Epsilon, so it's not really affecting growth anymore, but the traditional agency stuff is actually back into growth mode.

SANJAY SAKHRANI: Okay. I think we are going to have to end it right there. Thank you, Ed. Appreciate it.

ED HEFFERNAN: Okay. Thank you.

urn:contentItem:5WXM-B7J1-DXVP-500R-00000-00Allianz-Backed AV8 Ventures Taps Google Cloud Exec Baris Aksoy As Newest General Partner2019-08-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:08:51ZLexisNexisAllianz-Backed AV8 Ventures Taps Google Cloud Exec Baris Aksoy As Newest General PartnerCatherine PerloffForbes Staff

Eighteen-month old AV8 Ventures brings on Google Cloud Exec Baris Aksoy to expand their push into enterprise software & machine learning.

A venture firm backed by insurance giant Allianz is getting a boost from one of Silicon Valley s biggest names. 

Eighteen-month-old firm AV8 Ventures announced on Wednesday it s hired Google Cloud executive Baris Aksoy as a general partner. Aksoy joins managing partners George Ugras and Miles Kirby in the leadership of the $170 million fund, which focuses on early-stage investments in machine learning, artificial intelligence, healthcare and mobility. 

Aksoy joins from Google Cloud, where he ran the media and entertainment vertical, helping broadcasters conduct their business operations without legacy servers. He d previously founded a data visualization startup that ultimately went belly up, invested in startups personally and then joined video streaming startup Avanto as chief financial officer. Aksoy ended up at Google when the tech giant acquired Avanto in 2016. 

The cloud exec isn t new to venture capital. Earlier in his career, he was an investor at Intel Capital, the venture arm of chipmaker Intel, leading several successful exits. But unlike some investors who look to work their way up the ranks within one shop, Aksoy says he was eager to start again at the bottom as an entrepreneur. Unless you really understand the pains of the founder, it s really hard to add value [as an investor], so I took almost a 5-year break from venture capital, he says. 

That corporate investor to founder and big-tech exec journey made Aksoy attractive to AV8 Ventures, which says it operates independently but counts German asset management and insurance giant Allianz as its sole limited partner. To Ugras, Aksoy brings a founder-empathetic approach that contrasts with a sea of transactional investors in the market. This business was started in the 1960s and it was really about company-building, he says something AV8 believes is lost in the age of the unicorn.

Aksoy says he plans to invest in startups that help companies manage their data in the wake of new privacy regulations in Europe and California, integrate cloud software with existing on-premise systems and protect digital assets against cyber threats.

He joins a firm that while young its fund only formally closed in April has made seven investments to date, including home healthcare workflow platform Swift Shift and Contract Wrangler, which is applying machine learning to contracts, as well as startups in healthcare, weather and autonomous trucking. Ugras says the firm hopes to see Aksoy continue its efforts in finding real use cases for the buzzy machine learning category, one he says hasn t fulfilled its heady promise so far.

While AV8 is far from the only cloud-focused or corporate-backed VC firm, Aksoy and his colleagues hope their approach will stand out against a Silicon Valley culture currently obsessed with success and victory laps. I hear some investors talking about their investments and bets, says Aksoy. We are not that.

urn:contentItem:5XW7-W8K1-JBG3-64KY-00000-00Alligator Skin, Human Clones and Other Things Being Banned in 20202019-12-31T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:08:51ZLexisNexisUSAlligator Skin, Human Clones and Other Things Being Banned in 2020Vanessa Swales

Jan. 1 is a popular time for new laws to take effect. This year, some states are instituting bans (or trying to), while others are protecting privacy or public safety.

Jan. 1 is a popular time for new laws to take effect. This year, some states are instituting bans (or trying to), while others are protecting privacy or public safety.

California lawmakers made their fashion ruling: Crocodile handbags were out. Alligator boots, too. But for Louisiana, the nation’s top producer of all things made from alligator skin, those were fighting words.

The state’s attorney general filed a federal lawsuit earlier this month to stop California’s ban on alligator and crocodile products from taking effect in 2020. Last week, a federal judge agreed to temporarily block the new law, meaning Louisiana and California are headed for a showdown in court.

Every year on Jan. 1, hundreds of new state and federal laws take effect across the country. Many are mundane, but some can be contentious — and not just in the world of fashion.

As 2020 arrives on Wednesday, Arkansas will ban state-funded human cloning, while Illinois will legalize marijuana. Texas will try to save lives in school shootings, but not by taking action on guns. Here’s a look at changes coming across the country.

Requiring gunshot wound kits in schools

When a gunman opened fire at a high school in Santa Clarita, Calif., in November, a choir teacher barricaded her students behind a grand piano and grabbed a gunshot wound kit, wrapping the wounds of a freshman girl who had been shot in the torso and shoulder. The girl survived.

In Texas, which has seen its own rash of mass shootings, a new law will require local school districts to stock similar kits on their campuses, equipped with tourniquets, chest seals, compression bandages, bleeding-control bandages, emergency blankets, latex-free gloves, markers and scissors. University Health System, a San Antonio-based public hospital, will train students and school employees to use them.

No public money for embryo research

Arkansas lawmakers voted to prohibit state funding of human cloning or destructive embryo research, stating that the “prospect of creating new human life solely to be exploited or destroyed has been condemned on moral grounds as displaying a profound disrespect for a human life.”

The new law will also block funds to state educational institutions investigating stem cell research using embryos. In vitro fertilization, however, will not be affected.

Arizona, Maryland and Missouri prohibit the use of state funds to pay for reproductive cloning, while North Dakota, South Dakota and Oklahoma are the only states to ban all forms of human cloning.

A groundbreaking data privacy law

Wondering why you’re seeing a flurry of “updates to our terms of service and privacy policy” emails in your inbox?

California, home of some of the country’s big tech giants, such as Google, Facebook and Yahoo, is rolling out a landmark digital privacy law that will regulate data collection from consumers. The California Consumer Privacy Act requires companies to comply with new privacy and transparency standards.

Consumers will be able to request access to information that tech companies have collected about them and ask that the data be deleted. Users can also opt out of companies selling their personal data — including photos, and information on what they buy and where they go — to other businesses.

California is the first place to implement such a law in the United States. In 2018, the European Union’s data protection law took effect, protecting all residents in the member countries.

Recreational marijuana expands in the Midwest

Illinois will become the 11th state in the country, and the second in the Midwest, to legalize recreational marijuana sales and use. As early as 6 a.m. on New Year’s Day, anyone 21 and over with a valid driver’s license will be able to purchase cannabis products at state-licensed stores.

The state has approved 35 medical cannabis dispensaries to sell pot and other products. There are, however, limits on how much an individual can purchase: 30 grams of marijuana, 500 milligrams of edibles and five grams of concentrated THC oils.

A ban on alligator products, blocked

The state was set to institute a ban on any merchandise made of alligator or crocodile skin, including popular boots and handbags, until the Louisiana attorney general’s office filed a lawsuit and a federal judge issued a hold.

“The temporary restraining order is the first step in protecting Louisiana’s alligator industry, which creates jobs, supports our economy and contributes to much-needed coastal restoration efforts,” Gov. John Bel Edwards of Louisiana said in a news release Friday.

Louisiana is the United States’ leading producer of alligator skins, according to the Louisiana Alligator Advisory Council. In 2017, the alligator industry generated almost $100 million for the state, the group said.

California will still go ahead with a ban on cosmetics companies importing or selling products that have been tested on animals.

Ending cash bail could release thousands of inmates

New York will become the latest state to eliminate cash bail for misdemeanors and nonviolent felonies, which could see more than 40 percent of inmates released from pretrial detention, according to   the Center for Court Innovation.

Bail can still be set for people accused of more violent crimes, including sexual offenses, domestic abuse, witness tampering and conspiracy to commit murder. When deciding whether to set bail on those cases, judges are still expected to consider the defendant’s financial ability to pay.

Over the past few years, several states have taken similar steps as part of an effort to reduce the criminalization of poverty. California became the first state to abolish cash bail entirely last year.   New Jersey has also all but eliminated cash bail, while New Mexico has minimized its use.

Previous salary: Don’t ask, you’re not allowed

Employers in New Jerseywill be banned from screening applicants based on their past salaries or benefits history or asking what they previously earned, a rule intended to address the gender wage gap and promote equal pay among workers. Seventeen states — including California, Hawaii and Maine — have passed similar laws. And in recent years, such laws at the county level have been passed across the country.

Another ‘red flag’ law to reduce gun violence

Since the Columbine High School shooting in 1999, Colorado has suffered several more mass shootings. The state will now become the latest to implement a “red flag” law, which will allow family members or law enforcement officials to petition a court to confiscate firearms from people who are deemed by a judge to be a danger to themselves or others.

Colorado follows in the footsteps of at least 17 states, including Florida, New York, Connecticut, Illinois, Indiana and California, which have approved some version of a red flag law. In Colorado, the seizure of firearms can be extended to 364 days, after which the burden of proof is on owners to have their firearms returned.

Gift cards, composting and zero-emission vehicles

Some new state laws won’t take effect until the summer. Beginning July 1, businesses in Washington State will be banned from putting expiration dates on gift cards. The new law will protect recipients if they do not use their gift cards in a timely fashion, and service charges will no longer be allowed.

Vermont residents will not be able to throw peels, eggshells, seeds, pits, bones, coffee grounds, loose-leaf tea, oil and other food scraps in landfills beginning on July 1. Trucking companies will be required by the state’s universal recycling law to provide scrap collection services to all residents and businesses. Supermarkets and restaurants will also have to comply with mandatory composting across the state.

Car owners across a number of states, including California, Hawaii, Kansas and Alabama, will be charged fees to register “zero emission” vehicles in the new year. With the growing trend of green technology, these special fees, which range from $50 to $200, are expected to make up lost gas-tax revenue that pays for upgrading and repairing roads and bridges across the country.

PHOTO: California is trying to ban products made of alligator and crocodile. Louisiana isn’t happy. (PHOTOGRAPH BY Tim Graham/Getty Images FOR THE NEW YORK TIMES)

urn:contentItem:5XWS-3WH1-JD88-32KN-00000-00Alligator Skin, Human Clones and Other Things Being Banned in 20202020-01-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:08:51ZLexisNexisAlligator Skin, Human Clones and Other Things Being Banned in 2020

California lawmakers made their fashion ruling: Crocodile handbags were out. Alligator boots, too. But for Louisiana, the nations top producer of all things made from alligator skin, those were fighting words.

The states attorney general filed a federal lawsuit earlier this month to stop Californias ban on alligator and crocodile products from taking effect in 2020. Last week, a federal judge agreed to temporarily block the new law , meaning Louisiana and California are headed for a showdown in court.

Every year on Jan. 1, hundreds of new state and federal laws take effect across the country. Many are mundane, but some can be contentious and not just in the world of fashion.

As 2020 arrives on Wednesday, Arkansas will ban state-funded human cloning, while Illinois will legalize marijuana. Texas will try to save lives in school shootings, but not by taking action on guns. Heres a look at changes coming across the country.

Texas

Requiring gunshot wound kits in schools

When a gunman opened fire at a high school in Santa Clarita, Calif., in November, a choir teacher barricaded her students behind a grand piano and grabbed a gunshot wound kit, wrapping the wounds of a freshman girl who had been shot in the torso and shoulder. The girl survived.

In Texas, which has seen its own rash of mass shootings, a new law will require local school districts to stock similar kits on their campuses, equipped with tourniquets, chest seals, compression bandages, bleeding-control bandages, emergency blankets, latex-free gloves, markers and scissors. University Health System, a San Antonio-based public hospital, will train students and school employees to use them.

Arkansas

No public money for embryo research

Arkansas lawmakers voted to prohibit state funding of human cloning or destructive embryo research, stating that the prospect of creating new human life solely to be exploited or destroyed has been condemned on moral grounds as displaying a profound disrespect for a human life.

The new law will also block funds to state educational institutions investigating stem cell research using embryos. In vitro fertilization, however, will not be affected.

Arizona, Maryland and Missouri prohibit the use of state funds to pay for reproductive cloning, while North Dakota, South Dakota and Oklahoma are the only states to ban all forms of human cloning.

California

A groundbreaking data privacy law

Wondering why youre seeing a flurry of updates to our terms of service and privacy policy emails in your inbox?

California, home of some of the countrys big tech giants, such as Google, Facebook and Yahoo, is rolling out a landmark digital privacy law that will regulate data collection from consumers. The California Consumer Privacy Act requires companies to comply with new privacy and transparency standards.

Consumers will be able to request access to information that tech companies have collected about them and ask that the data be deleted. Users can also opt out of companies selling their personal data including photos, and information on what they buy and where they go to other businesses.

California is the first place to implement such a law in the United States. In 2018, the European Unions data protection law took effect, protecting all residents in the member countries.

Illinois

Recreational marijuana expands in the Midwest

Illinois will become the 11th state in the country, and the second in the Midwest, to legalize recreational marijuana sales and use. As early as 6 a.m. on New Years Day, anyone 21 and over with a valid drivers license will be able to purchase cannabis products at state-licensed stores.

The state has approved 35 medical cannabis dispensaries to sell pot and other products. There are, however, limits on how much an individual can purchase: 30 grams of marijuana, 500 milligrams of edibles and five grams of concentrated THC oils.

California

A ban on alligator products, blocked

The state was set to institute a ban on any merchandise made of alligator or crocodile skin, including popular boots and handbags, until the Louisiana attorney generals office filed a lawsuit and a federal judge issued a hold.

The temporary restraining order is the first step in protecting Louisianas alligator industry, which creates jobs, supports our economy and contributes to much-needed coastal restoration efforts, Gov. John Bel Edwards of Louisiana said in a news release Friday.

Louisiana is the United States leading producer of alligator skins , according to the Louisiana Alligator Advisory Council. In 2017, the alligator industry generated almost $100 million for the state, the group said.

California will still go ahead with a ban on cosmetics companies importing or selling products that have been tested on animals.

NEW YORK

Ending cash bail could release thousands of inmates

New York will become the latest state to eliminate cash bail for misdemeanors and nonviolent felonies, which could see more than 40 percent of inmates released from pretrial detention, according to the Center for Court Innovation .

Bail can still be set for people accused of more violent crimes, including sexual offenses, domestic abuse, witness tampering and conspiracy to commit murder. When deciding whether to set bail on those cases, judges are still expected to consider the defendants financial ability to pay.

Over the past few years, several states have taken similar steps as part of an effort to reduce the criminalization of poverty. California became the first state to abolish cash bail entirely last year. New Jersey has also all but eliminated cash bail , while New Mexico has minimized its use.

New Jersey

Previous salary: Dont ask, youre not allowed

Employers in New Jersey will be banned from screening applicants based on their past salaries or benefits history or asking what they previously earned, a rule intended to address the gender wage gap and promote equal pay among workers. Seventeen states including California, Hawaii and Maine have passed similar laws. And in recent years, such laws at the county level have been passed across the country.

Colorado

Another red flag law to reduce gun violence

Since the Columbine High School shooting in 1999, Colorado has suffered several more mass shootings. The state will now become the latest to implement a red flag law, which will allow family members or law enforcement officials to petition a court to confiscate firearms from people who are deemed by a judge to be a danger to themselves or others.

Colorado follows in the footsteps of at least 17 states , including Florida, New York, Connecticut, Illinois, Indiana and California, which have approved some version of a red flag law. In Colorado, the seizure of firearms can be extended to 364 days, after which the burden of proof is on owners to have their firearms returned.

LOOKING AHEAD

Gift cards, composting and zero-emission vehicles

Some new state laws wont take effect until the summer. Beginning July 1, businesses in Washington State will be banned from putting expiration dates on gift cards. The new law will protect recipients if they do not use their gift cards in a timely fashion, and service charges will no longer be allowed.

Vermont residents will not be able to throw peels, eggshells, seeds, pits, bones, coffee grounds, loose-leaf tea, oil and other food scraps in landfills beginning on July 1. Trucking companies will be required by the states universal recycling law to provide scrap collection services to all residents and businesses. Supermarkets and restaurants will also have to comply with mandatory composting across the state.

Car owners across a number of states, including California, Hawaii, Kansas and Alabama, will be charged fees to register zero emission vehicles in the new year. With the growing trend of green technology, these special fees, which range from $50 to $200, are expected to make up lost gas-tax revenue that pays for upgrading and repairing roads and bridges across the country.

urn:contentItem:5W89-1211-DXH2-63SB-00000-00ALL IN WITH CHRIS HAYES for June 3, 20192019-06-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:08:51ZLexisNexisALL IN with CHRIS HAYES8:00 PM ESTDavid Cicilline, Elizabeth Holtzman, Adam Jentleson, Chris Murphy, John Hickenlooper, Jennifer RubinNEWSDomestic060301cb.478ALL IN WITH CHRIS HAYES for June 3, 2019Chris Hayes, Jacob Soboroff

The Judiciary Committee will hear from legal experts and former U.S. attorneys on the findings of the Mueller report. Mitch McConnell denies votes on series of bills passed by the House. Rep. David Cicilline (D-RI) is interviewed about impeaching President Donald Trump. Sen. Chris Murphy (D-CT) is interviewed about the Senate blocking bill after bill passed from the House of Representatives.

CHRIS MATTHEWS, MSNBC HOST: That`s our HARDBALL town hall. "ALL IN" with Chris Hayes starts right now.

MAYOR PETE BUTTIGIEG (D), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: Thank you.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CHRIS HAYES, MSNBC HOST: Tonight on ALL IN.

REP. NANCY PELOSI (D-CA), SPEAKER OF THE HOUSE: What is the president covering up?

HAYES: The pressure to impeach.

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: To me, it`s a dirty word the word impeach.

HAYES: With at least 58 House members signaling support and the first Mueller hearing a week away, where do Democrats stand on impeachment?

REP. JAMES CLYBURN (D-SC): We`ve already begun it.

HAYES: Then exclusive new reporting on children separated from their parents. Plus, Senator Chris Murphy on the gun legislation stalled in the Senate, and the president`s son-in-law on Mideast peace and his father-in- law`s Birtherism.

JARED KUSHNER, SENIOR ADVISOR TO THE PRESIDENT: I wasn`t really involved in that.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I know you would. Was it racist?

KUSHNER: Like I said, I wasn`t involved in that.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I know you would, was it racist?

HAYES: When ALL IN starts right now.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

HAYES: Good evening from New York I`m Chris Hayes. Well, they`re not calling them impeachment proceedings but one week from today, the House Judiciary Committee will hold the first in a series of hearings on what its announcement refers to as "presidential obstruction and other crimes."

House Judiciary is, of course, the committee responsible for starting the impeachment process should they choose to do so and at least half the Democratic members of that committee are now on the record calling for just that.

As of tonight, a total of 58 House members have come out in support of a formal impeachment inquiry, a number of this grown steadily since Robert Mueller told the public last week in his own voice that he was unable to conclude that the President is not a criminal.

Lawmakers were back in Washington today for the first time since Mueller broke his silence after spending the past week working in their home districts. During that time, some of them were confronted by voters demanding they get more aggressive including House Speaker Nancy Pelosi whose speech at the California Democratic Party Convention was interrupted by calls were impeachment.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

PELOSI: Why is it that the President won`t defend our democracy from this foreign threat? What is the president covering up? The report lays out 11 instances of possible obstruction of justice by the President of the United States. I told you this is like coming home for me.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

HAYES: Another member of House Democratic leadership, House Homeland Security Chair Bennie Thompson told me that he decided to come out in support of impeachment only after talking to his constituents.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. BENNIE THOMPSON (D-MS): Up until I came home this weekend I had resisted moving forward. But you know, I represent this district and I listen to the people and I heard them. It didn`t matter whether I was in the hole in the wall or the finest restaurant in my district, people would have come up and talked to me about this. And let me tell you, it bothers them.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

HAYES: First up next week, the Judiciary Committee will hear from legal experts and former U.S. attorneys on the findings of the Mueller report. They will also hear testimony from the former White House Counsel, not from Don McGahn who defied a subpoena to testify two weeks ago citing the President`s invocation of executive privilege. Instead, the committee will hear from Richard Nixon`s White House Counsel John Dean whose public testimony on the Watergate cover-up was a major turning point in that scandal.

These hearings represent a compromise of sorts between different factions of the House Democratic caucus which disagree on strategy on the end on whether to use the I-word as the president calls it. One thing there doesn`t seem to be a whole lot of disagreement on within that caucus is that the President deserves to be impeached whether or not it`s politically smart.

That his conduct as seen in public and the Mueller report already meets the threshold of high crimes and misdemeanors, so much so that the number three House Democrat now says impeachment proceedings are all but inevitable.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CLYBURN: We do believe that if we sufficiently, effectively educate the public, then we will have done our jobs and we can move on an impeachment vote.

JAMES TAPPER, HOST, CNN: But it sounds like you`re -- you think that the president will be impeached or at least proceedings will begin in the House at some point but just not right now.

CLYBURN: Yes, exactly what I feel. I think we`ve already begun it.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

HAYES: I`m joined now by a member of the House Judiciary Committee who supports starting an impeachment inquiry Congressman David Cicilline Democrat from Rhode Island. Congressman, tell me what this hearing a week from today is designed to do?

REP. DAVID CICILLINE (D-RI): Well, Chris, it`s designed to provide some context with respect to the Mueller report. We`ll hear from legal scholars, one -- several of the nearly thousand U.S. attorneys who have signed a letter that said the conduct of the president would amount to obstruction of justice and he would be charged if you were not the president.

We`ll hear from John Dean who knows something about cover-ups and the way a corrupt administration operates. But your kind of lead-in suggest there`s big divisions in the caucus. I would really say to you that the Democratic caucus is unified on two critical points. One is that we must hold this president accountable, that no one is above the law, that the president cannot continue to cover up and prevent us from getting to the truth.

And secondly, that in addition to holding him accountable that we need to continue to deliver on the important priorities the American people elected us to focus on. Driving down the cost of health care, taking on the high cost of prescription drugs, rebuilding the infrastructure of our country, raising family incomes, and taking on the corruption in Washington.

We`ve passed over 100 pieces of legislation consistent with that agenda that will improve people`s lives. You`ve got to continue to do that. But the American people also expect us to hold this administration accountable. And there`s some disagreement in the caucus about the vehicle, the best vehicle to use but the hearings on Monday will be the beginning of our consideration of the contents of the Mueller report.

It will help bring that report to life for the American people and explain the crimes that are alleged ten separate instances of obstruction of justice including efforts by the President to create false documents or encourage people to do that, to encourage people not to tell the truth. These are serious, serious allegations in the Mueller report.

HAYES: In terms of holding the president accountable, there`s also this question of who you can get before your committee. Obviously, Don McGahn, Bill Barr have both defied your subpoenas. I see that there`s going to be a vote on Tuesday for contempt it appears for both of those individuals. How do you see where things stand vis a vis the kind of obstruction of Congress that the executive has doubled down on?

CICILLINE: Well, I think there`s no question that all the members of the committee and all the members of the Democratic caucus believe that critical that we have the ability to get witnesses and get documents that we need to conduct our investigations. If we allow the executive branch to simply deny us witnesses or deny documents, the executive branch will be allowed to extinguish congressional oversight.

That cannot happen. People cannot defy lawfully issued subpoenas so we`re really running on two tracks. We`ll begin these hearings, a series of hearings before the Judiciary Committee. At the same time we will move forward on contempt proceedings to compel the attendance of witnesses and the production of documents. That`s what the vote will be next week that will authorize a civil enforcement action.

But we really want to make it very clear that we intend to do our work, we intend to use the courts to enforce us subpoenas so we can get to the truth and that we can prevent the president from behaving as if he`s above the law and trying to keep this ongoing cover-up from continuing.

HAYES: I want to get your response to a little bit of reporting about the President and this has to do with something that you`re working on in your Subcommittee on the Antitrust. In 2017, the president repeatedly told aids such as Gary Cohn and Rob Porter, and John Kelly to try to block the AT&TTime Warner merger. They didn`t listen.

His tweet today in which he suggested a boycott as part of a long campaign to punish a network whose coverage it. Am I`m wrong or that that in and of itself opens up the possibility of impeachment? Like using the antitrust powers of the executive to punish bad coverage, where does that stand in your mind?

CICILLINE: Yes. It`s a complete abuse of power. Look, the antitrust enforcement that is required by the Department of Justice is a quasi- judicial proceeding. It has to be free from any political interference. Those are judgments that have to be made based on the facts.

It`s completely improper for a president to attempt in any way to interfere. And the idea of using the power of the Department of Justice to punish people that he perceives are giving him bad coverage is a gross abuse of the office. And we`ll obviously be part of or conducting an investigation on with respect to the Antitrust Subcommittee of the whole issue of antitrust.

HAYES: Yes, you announced big efforts to look into big tech through that committee today. It`s very interesting stuff. I want to have you come back and talk to us about that as that perceives. Congressman David Cicilline, thank you very much.

CICILLINE: My pleasure. Thank you.

HAYES: For more on the first hearing on the Mueller report, I`m joined by Adam Jentleson former Deputy Chief of Staff and Strategic Adviser of Harry Reid when he was Democratic leader in the Senate and former Congresswoman Elizabeth Holtzman who served on the Judiciary Committee when it drafted articles of impeachment against Richard Nixon. She`s authored The Case for Impeaching Trump.

It`s interesting to me, it seems that they have the Venn diagram of the various parts of the caucus are like well, we should definitely have some hearings about what this guy is up to and that`s what we`re getting next week.

ELIZABETH HOLTZMAN, FORMER CONGRESSWOMAN: Right I think the real problem that the Democrats face -- well, people who care about democracy face is that the witnesses who could tell the story are not showing up. And how do you get them? The really critical thing is to get the story of the Mueller report to the American people. You can`t hand a report to a jury and say convict somebody. You`ve got to have live witnesses and that`s the problem here. The story of the Mueller report hasn`t been told to the American people.

HAYES: And it hasn`t been told in the first person by the people there, like for instance Don McGahn. I mean, John Dean, God bless him, but John Dean was -- he was there 30 years ago, 40 years ago, he wasn`t there now. Don McGahn sitting out there but they can`t get him to come before the committee.

HOLTZMAN: Right. And so what they trying to do is figure out how to do that and that`s a critical problem for them.

HAYES: Adam, you know, you`ve -- it`s been interesting to listen to you talk about this because you`re someone who has been an insider. I mean, you were -- you were in Senator Harry Reid`s office. You know that the view from inside looks very different. Sometimes the view from outside, sometimes I think properly so, and sometimes in a blinkered fashion.

I`m curious what you make of the strategy right now and particularly Pelosi his appearance before the California Democratic Party.

ADAM JENTLESON, FORMER SENIOR AIDE, MAJORITY LEADER HARRY REID: Well, you know, I mean Speaker Pelosi has to bring the caucus along. I mean, that`s just a fact. You can`t just come out and announce that she favors impeachment if the caucus isn`t there.

But I think one of the things that was interesting about her appearance was that you know, she laid out the case for essentially why the president deserved to be impeached without saying he deserved to be impeached. And that`s sort of one of the things they`re dealing with here is that you know, if they lay out the sort of bill of particulars against the president, the automatic reflex question is well so doesn`t he deserve to be impeached.

It`s very hard to make the substantive case that this line they`re trying to walk right now of trying to make the substantive case against him without saying the I-word tricky because they have the power to do it and it and it just you know begs the question why they don`t use the power.

HAYES: Yes. There`s this sort of semantic wrinkle here. I mean, when I saw -- when I saw them noticing the hearing and the title is a presidential structure and other crimes, it`s like well, they`re crimes. Like crimes mean crimes. If you`re caught on crimes then that`s kind of the territory we`re in.

HOLTZMAN: Right. Well, you don`t need a crime to be impeached. And I think, you know, they have to be really careful about the language they use. I would have said obstruction of justice and other abuses of power, because I think you fall into a trap that the American people expect that you can prove that he committed a crime.

HAYES: Right. And abuse of power, you know, this -- Adam, this little blip right, this just passed today. It`ll get a little bit of nose. The president tells his advisers go block this murderer because I don`t like the way the company is reporting on me. It`s the perfect Trump example because it`s obviously to me, it`s an obvious abuse of power. I think it meets the threshold for high crimes and misdemeanors but they all just ignore him.

I mean, time and time again, the guy tries to commit masses abuses of power and fails in doing so because so many people around him are like just wait, wait the guy out. You can`t trust him. And that`s I think part of the problem the Democrats have.

JENTLESON: Right. Well, that`s right. And except for the fact that as of January 1st, 2019 they have the power to do something about it.

HAYES: Right.

JENTLESON: And I think you know, Trump got used to two years of being in control of the White House with a compliant Republican Congress where nobody was doing anything about it and he got in that habit. And Democrats I think in some ways got used to the fact that it feels powerless because the media would eventually move on and the story eventually moves on, but they have the power now.

And they have the power for the first time to actually do something about these abuses of power and it really is incumbent on them to do it.

HAYES: I want to play you something -- you know, we`ve been watching the sort of presidential candidates react to this and Mayor Pete Buttigieg was on Town Hall right before our hour, really fascinating. This is him in Chris Matthews talking about this question of impeachment. He comes right out and says what he would do. Take a listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BUTTIGIEG: So I do recognize that while we`re still trying to get information, the investigations are ongoing, there are witnesses yet to come before Congress, that there may be some strategic wisdom in following that sequence. I`ll leave that to Congress.

MATTHEWS: I`ve got a follow-up and it`s to sort of nail you down. If you were voting in Congress right now on impeachment, would you vote to impeach?

BUTTIGIEG: I would.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

HAYES: Its hard -- to Adam`s point, right. I mean, that`s -- the problem is when you lay out you say look, I think the guy is abusing power and he`s committed -- he`s abused the office, you know, you end up in tails into something.

HOLTZMAN: Right. Well, look, there are a lot of parallels with Nixon. That`s what I write about in my book. The dangling pardon, says what Nixon was Nixon was impeached for, firing the special prosecutor. That`s what Nixon was impeached for.

HAYES: Right. But Nixon -- but Nixon succeeded in do it and Trump didn`t. I mean so many of --

HOLTZMAN: And he did. Trump did fired the special prosecutor -- I`m sorry, he fired Comey.

HAYES: Right. He fired Comey.

HOLTZMAN: And he tried to fire --

HAYES: But then he tried to basically end his own presidency by firing Mueller and Don McGahn wouldn`t let him do it.

HOLTZMAN: Right. But in the end, Nixon didn`t succeed in undermining our government.

HAYES: Right.

HOLTZMAN: And neither will this president. So there`s plenty out there. The question is how do you bring the American people long. Mueller sets out part of the case and it`s critical to bring the American people along, educate them. And that`s what happened in Watergate. Let`s follow that blueprint.

HAYES: Final thing, Adam. You know, we`re going to -- our next segment is about some of the legislation that`s sitting on Mitch McConnell`s desk. And it`s true this House has done a tremendous amount in terms of passing a lot of stuff whether you agree with legislation or not. But I think you know, you saw Cicilline talking about two tracks. There`s this idea that like, the domestic legislation passed the House can be the kind of message for Democrats and I wonder what you think of that.

JENTLESON: Yes, I mean, you know, the House Democrats are proud of the fact that they ran on health care in 2018 and that`s very important. But there`s a difference now which is that in 2017 and 2018, the prospect of Republicans taking away people`s health care, repealing and replacing the Affordable Care Act was a live possibility that drove a constant flood of news out of Washington so that buoyed Democrats message.
